books.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:1
verses.text: Sacred History, Book I:   Chapter I.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:2
verses.text: I address myself to give a condensed account of those things which are set forth in the sacred Scriptures from the beginning of the world and to tell of them, with distinction of dates and according to their importance, down to period within our own remembrance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:3
verses.text: Many who were anxious to become acquainted with divine things by means of a compendious treatise, have eagerly entreated me to undertake this work.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:4
verses.text: I, seeking to carry out their wish, have not spared my labor, and have thus succeeded in comprising in two short books things which elsewhere filled many volumes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:5
verses.text: At the same time, in studying brevity, I have omitted hardly any of the facts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:6
verses.text: Moreover, it seemed to me not out of place that, after I had run through the sacred history down to the crucifixion of Christ, and the doings of the Apostles, I should add an account of events which subsequently took place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:7
verses.text: I am, therefore, to tell of the destruction of Jerusalem, the persecutions of the Christian people, the times of peace which followed, and of all things again thrown into confusion by the intestine dangers of the churches.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:8
verses.text: But I will not shrink from confessing that, wherever reason required, I have made use of profane historians to fix dates and preserve the series of events unbroken, and have taken out of these what was wanting to a complete knowledge of the facts, that I might both instruct the ignorant and carry conviction to the learned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:9
verses.text: Nevertheless, as to those things which I have condensed from the sacred books, I do not wish so to present myself as an author to my readers, that they, neglecting the source from which my materials have been derived, should be satisfied with what I have written.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:10
verses.text: My aim is that one who is already familiar with the original should recognize here what he has read there; for all the mysteries of divine things cannot be brought out except from the fountain-head itself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 1:11
verses.text: I shall now enter upon my narrative.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:2
verses.text: The world was created by God nearly six thousand years ago, as we shall set forth in the course of this book; although those who have entered upon and published a calculation of the dates, but little agree among themselves.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:3
verses.text: As, however, this disagreement is due either to the will of God or to the fault of antiquity, it ought not to be a matter of censure.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:4
verses.text: After the formation of the world man was created, the male being named Adam, and the female Eve.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:5
verses.text: Having been placed in Paradise, they ate of the tree from which they were interdicted, and therefore were cast forth as exiles into our earth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:6
verses.text: To them were born Cain and Abel; but Cain, being an impious man, slew his brother.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:7
verses.text: He had a son called Enoch, by whom a city was first built, and was called after the name of its founder.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:8
verses.text: From him Irad, and from him again Maüiahel was descended.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:9
verses.text: He had a son called Mathusalam, and he, in turn, begat Lamech, by whom a young man is said to have been slain, without, however, the name of the slain man being mentioned—a fact which is thought by the wise to have presaged a future mystery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:10
verses.text: Adam, then, after the death of his younger son, begat another son called Seth, when he was now two hundred and thirty years old: he lived altogether eight hundred and thirty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:11
verses.text: Seth begat Enos, Enos Cainan, Cainan Malaleel, Malaleel Jared, and Jared Enoch, who on account of his righteousness is said to have been translated by God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:12
verses.text: His son was called Mathusalam who begat Lamech; from whom Noah was descended, remarkable for his righteousness, and above all other mortals dear and acceptable to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:13
verses.text: When by this time the human race had increased to a great multitude, certain angels, whose habitation was in heaven, were captivated by the appearance of some beautiful virgins, and cherished illicit desires after them, so much so, that falling beneath their own proper nature and origin, they left the higher regions of which they  were inhabitants, and allied themselves in earthly marriages.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 2:14
verses.text: These angels gradually spreading wicked habits, corrupted the human family, and from their alliance giants are said to have sprung, for the mixture with them of beings of a different nature, as a matter of course, gave birth to monsters.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:2
verses.text: God being offended by these things, and especially by the wickedness of mankind, which had gone beyond measure, had determined to destroy the whole human race.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:3
verses.text: But he exempted Noah, a righteous man and of blameless life, from the destined doom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:4
verses.text: He being warned by God that a flood was coming upon the earth, built an ark of wood of immense size, and covered it with pitch so as to render it impervious to water.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:5
verses.text: He was shut into it along with his wife, and his three sons and his three daughters-in-law.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:6
verses.text: Pairs of birds also and of the different kinds of beasts were likewise received into it, while all the rest were cut off by a flood.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:7
verses.text: Noah then, when he understood that the violence of the rain had ceased, and that the ark was quietly floating on the deep, thinking (as really was the case) that the waters were decreasing, sent forth first a raven for the purpose of enquiring into the matter, and on its not returning, having settled, as I conjecture, on the dead bodies, he then sent forth a dove.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:8
verses.text: It, not finding a place of rest, returned to him and being again sent out, it brought back an olive leaf, in manifest proof that the tops of the trees were now to be seen.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:9
verses.text: Then being sent forth a third time, it returned no more, from which it was understood that the waters had subsided; and Noah accordingly went out from the ark.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 3:10
verses.text: This was done, as I reckon, two thousand two hundred and forty-two years after the beginning of the world.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:2
verses.text: Then Noah first of all erected an altar to God, and offered sacrifices from among the birds.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:3
verses.text: Immediately afterwards he was blessed by God along with his sons, and received a command that he should not eat blood, or shed the blood of any human being, because Cain, having no such precept, had stained the first age of the world.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:4
verses.text: Accordingly, the sons of Noah were alone left in the then vacant world; for he had three, Shem, Ham, and Japhet.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:5
verses.text: But Ham, because he had mocked his father when senseless with wine, incurred his father's curse.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:6
verses.text: His son, Chas by name, begat the giant Nebroth, by whom the city of Babylon is said to have been built.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:7
verses.text: Many other towns are related to have been founded at that time, which I do not here intend to name one by one.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:8
verses.text: But although the human race was now multiplied, and men occupied different places and islands, nevertheless all made use of one tongue, as long as the multitude, afterwards to be scattered through the whole world, kept itself in one body.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:9
verses.text: These, after the manner of human nature, formed the design of obtaining a great name by constructing some great work before they should be separated from one another.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:10
verses.text: They therefore attempted to build a tower which should reach up to heaven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:11
verses.text: But by the ordination of God, in order that the labors of those engaged in the work might be hindered, they began to speak in a kind of languages very different from their accustomed form of speech, while no one understood the others.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:12
verses.text: This led to their being all the more readily dispersed, because, regarding each other as foreigners, they were easily induced to separate.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:13
verses.text: And the world was so divided to the sons of Noah, that Shem occupied the East, Japhet the West, and Ham the intermediate parts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 4:14
verses.text: After this, till the time of Abraham, their genealogy presented nothing very remarkable or worthy of record.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:2
verses.text: Abraham, whose father was Thara, was born in the one thousand and seventeenth year after the deluge.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:3
verses.text: His wife was called Sara, and his dwelling-place was at first in the country of the Chaldaeans.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:4
verses.text: He then dwelt along with his father at Charrae.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:5
verses.text: Being at this time spoken to by God, he left his country and his father, and taking with him Lot, the son of his brother, he came into the country of the Canaanites, and settled at a place named Sychem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:6
verses.text: Ere long, owing to the want of corn, he went into Egypt, and again returned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:7
verses.text: Lot, owing to the size of the household, parted from his uncle, that he might take advantage of more spacious territories in what was then a vacant region, and settled at Sodom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:8
verses.text: That town was infamous on account of its inhabitants, males forcing themselves upon males, and it is said on that account to have been hateful to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:9
verses.text: At that period the kings of the neighboring peoples were in arms, though previously there had been no war among mankind.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:10
verses.text: But the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah and of the adjacent territories went forth to battle against those who were making war upon the regions round about, and being routed at the first onset, yielded the victory to the opposite side.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:11
verses.text: Then Sodom was plundered and made a spoil of by the victorious enemy, while Lot was led into captivity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:12
verses.text: When Abraham heard of this, he speedily armed his servants, to the number of three hundred and eighteen, and, stripping of their spoils and arms the kings flushed with victory, he put them to flight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:13
verses.text: Then he was blessed by Melchisedech the priest, and gave him tithes of the spoil.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 5:14
verses.text: He restored the remainder to those from whom it had been taken.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:2
verses.text: At the same time God spoke to Abraham, and promised that his seed was to be multiplied as the sand of the sea; and that his predicted seed would live in a land not his own, while his posterity would endure slavery in a hostile country for four hundred years, but would afterwards be restored to liberty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:3
verses.text: Then his name was changed, as well as that of his wife, by the addition of one letter; so that instead of Abram he was called Abraham, and, instead of Sara, she was called Sarra.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:4
verses.text: The mystery involved in this is by no means trifling, but it is not the part of this work to treat of it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:5
verses.text: At the same time, the law of circumcision was enjoined on Abraham, and he had by a maid-servant a son called Ishmael.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:6
verses.text: Moreover, when he himself was a hundred years old, and his wife ninety, God promised that they should have a son Isaac, the Lord having come to him along with two angels.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:7
verses.text: Then the angels being sent to Sodom, found Lot sitting in the gate of the city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:8
verses.text: He supposed them to be human beings, and welcomed them to share in his hospitality, and provided an entertainment for them in his house, but the wicked youth of the town demanded the new arrivals for impure purposes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:9
verses.text: Lot offered them his daughters in place of his guests, but they did not accept the offer, having a desire rather for things forbidden, and then Lot himself was laid hold of with vile designs.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:10
verses.text: The angels, however, speedily rescued him from danger, by causing blindness to fall upon the eyes of these unchaste sinners.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:11
verses.text: Then Lot, being informed by his guests that the town was to be destroyed, went away from it with his wife and daughters; but they were commanded not to look back upon it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:12
verses.text: His wife, however, not obeying this precept (in accordance with that evil tendency of human nature which renders it difficult to abstain from things forbidden), turned back her eyes, and is said to have been at once changed into a monument.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:13
verses.text: As for Sodom, it was burned to ashes by fire from heaven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 6:14
verses.text: And the daughters of Lot, imagining that the whole human race had perished, sought a union with their father while he was intoxicated, and hence sprung the race of Moab and Ammon.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:2
verses.text: Almost at the same time, when Abraham was now a hundred years old, his son Isaac was born.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:3
verses.text: Then Sara expelled the maid-servant by whom Abraham had had a son; and she is said to have dwelt in the desert along with her son, and defended by the help of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:4
verses.text: Not long after this, God tried the faith of Abraham, and required that his son Isaac should be sacrificed to him by his father.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:5
verses.text: Abraham did not hesitate to offer him, and had already laid the lad upon the altar, and was drawing the sword to slay him, when a voice came from heaven commanding him to spare the young man; and a ram was found at hand to be for a victim.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:6
verses.text: When the sacrifice was offered, God spoke to Abraham, and promised him those things which he had already said he would bestow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:7
verses.text: But Sara died in her one hundred and twenty-seventh year, and her body was, through the care of her husband, buried in Hebron, a town of the Canaanites, for Abraham was staying in that place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:8
verses.text: Then Abraham, seeing that his son Isaac was now of youthful age, for he was, in fact, in his fortieth year, enjoined his servant to seek a wife for him, but only from that tribe and territory from which he himself was known to be descended.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:9
verses.text: He was instructed, however, on finding the girl, to bring her into the land of the Canaanites, and not to suppose that Isaac would return into the country of his father for the purpose of obtaining a wife.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:10
verses.text: In order that the servant might carry out those instructions zealously, Abraham administered an oath to him, while his hand rested on the thigh of his master.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:11
verses.text: The servant accordingly set out for Mesopotamia, and came to the town of Nachor, the brother of Abraham.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:12
verses.text: He entered into the house of Bathuel, the Syrian, son of Nachor; and having seen Rebecca, a beautiful virgin, the daughter of Nachor, he asked for her, and brought her to his master.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:13
verses.text: After this, Abraham took a wife named Kethurah, who is called in the Chronicles his concubine, and begat children by her.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:14
verses.text: But he left his possessions to Isaac, the son of Sara, while, at the same time, he distributed gifts to those whom he had begotten by his concubines; and thus they were separated from Isaac.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 7:15
verses.text: Abraham  died after a life of a hundred and seventy-five years; and his body was laid in the tomb of Sara his wife.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:2
verses.text: Now, Rebecca, having long been barren, at length, through the unceasing prayers of her husband to the Lord, brought forth twins about twenty years after the time of her marriage.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:3
verses.text: These are said to have often leaped in the womb of their mother; and it was announced by the answer of the Lord on this subject, that two peoples were foretold in these children, and that the elder would, in rank, be inferior to the younger.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:4
verses.text: Well, the first that was born, bristling over with hair, was called Esau, while Jacob was the name given to the younger.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:5
verses.text: At that time, a grievous famine had taken place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:6
verses.text: Under the pressure of this necessity, Isaac went to Gerar, to King Abimelech, having been warned by the Lord not to go down into Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:7
verses.text: There he is promised the possession of the whole land, and is blessed, and having been greatly increased in cattle and every kind of substance, he is, under the influence of envy, driven out by the inhabitants.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:8
verses.text: Thus expelled from that region, he sojourned by the well, known as "the well of the oath".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:9
verses.text: By and by, being advanced in years, and his eyesight being gone, as he made ready to bless his son Esau, Jacob through the counsel of his mother, Rebecca, presented himself to be blessed in the place of his brother.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:10
verses.text: Thus Jacob is set before his brother as the one to be honored by the princes and the peoples.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:11
verses.text: Esau, enraged by these occurrences, plotted the death of his brother.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:12
verses.text: Jacob, owing to the fear thus excited, and by the advice of his mother, fled into Mesopotamia, having been urged by his father to take a wife of the house of Laban, Rebecca's brother: so great was their care, while they dwelt in a strange country, that their children should marry within their own kindred.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:13
verses.text: Thus Jacob, setting out for Mesopotamia, is said in sleep to have had a vision of the Lord; and on that account regarding the place of his dream as sacred, he took a stone from it; and he vowed that, if he returned in prosperity, the name of the pillar should be the "house of the Lord," and that he would devote to God the tithes of all the possessions he had gained.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 8:14
verses.text: Then he betook himself to Laban, his mother's brother, and was kindly received by him to share in his hospitality as the acknowledged son of his sister.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:2
verses.text: Laban had two daughters, Leah and Rachel; but Leah had tender eyes, while Rachel is said to have been beautiful.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:3
verses.text: Jacob, captivated by her beauty, burned with love for the virgin, and, asking her in marriage from the father, gave himself up to a servitude of seven years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:4
verses.text: But when the time was fulfilled, Leah was foisted upon him, and he was subjected to another servitude of seven years, after which Rachel was given him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:5
verses.text: But we are told that she was long barren, while Leah was fruitful.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:6
verses.text: Of the sons whom Jacob had by Leah, the following are the names: Reuben, Symeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulon, and a daughter Dinah; while there were born to him by the handmaid of Leah, Gad and Asher, and by the handmaid of Rachel, Dan and Naphtali.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:7
verses.text: But Rachel, after she had despaired of offspring, bare Joseph.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:8
verses.text: Then Jacob, being desirous of returning to his father, when Laban his father-in-law had given him a portion of the flock as a reward for his service, and Jacob the son-in-law, thinking him not to be acting justly in that matter, while he [also] suspected deceit on his part, privately departed about the thirtieth year after his arrival.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:9
verses.text: Rachel, without the knowledge of her husband, stole the idols of her father, and on account of this injury Laban followed his son-in-law, but not finding his idols, returned, after being reconciled, having straitly charged his son-in-law not to take other wives in addition to his daughters.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:10
verses.text: Then Jacob, going on his way, is said to have had a vision of angels and of the army of the Lord.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:11
verses.text: But, as he directed his journey past the region of Edom, which his brother Esau inhabited, suspecting the temper of Esau, he first sent messengers and gifts to try him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:12
verses.text: Then he went to meet his brother, but Jacob took care not to trust him beyond what he could help.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:13
verses.text: On the day before the brothers were to meet, God, taking a human form, is said to have wrestled with Jacob.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:14
verses.text: And when he had prevailed with God, still he was not ignorant that his adversary was no mere mortal; and therefore begged to be blessed by him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:15
verses.text: Then his name was changed by God, so that from Jacob he was called Israel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:16
verses.text: But when he, in turn, inquired of God the name of God, he was told that that should not be asked after because it was wonderful.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 9:17
verses.text: Moreover, from that wrestling, the breadth of Jacob's thigh shrank.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:2
verses.text: Israel, therefore, avoiding the house of his brother, sent forward his company to Salem, a town of the Shechemites, and there he pitched his tent on a spot which he had purchased.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:3
verses.text: Emor, a Chorraean prince, was the ruler of that town.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:4
verses.text: His son Sychem defiled Dinah, the daughter of Jacob by Leah.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:5
verses.text: Symeon and Levi, the brothers of Dinah, discovering this, cut off by a stratagem all those of the male sex in the town, and thus terribly avenged the injury done to their sister.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:6
verses.text: The town was plundered by the sons of Jacob, and all the spoil carried off.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:7
verses.text: Jacob is said to have been much displeased with these proceedings.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:8
verses.text: Soon after being instructed by God, he went to Bethel, and there erected an altar to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:9
verses.text: Then he fixed his tent in a part of the territory belonging to the tower Gader.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:10
verses.text: Rachel died in childbirth: the boy she bore was called Benjamin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:11
verses.text: Israel died at the age of one hundred and eighty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:12
verses.text: Now, Esau was mighty in wealth, and had taken to himself wives of the nation of the Canaanites.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:13
verses.text: I do not think that, in a work so concise as the present, I am called upon to mention his descendants, and, if any one is curious on the subject, he may turn to the original.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:14
verses.text: After the death of his father, Jacob stayed on in the place where Isaac had lived.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:15
verses.text: His other sons occasionally left him along with the flocks, for the sake of pasturage, but Joseph and the little Benjamin remained at home.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:16
verses.text: Joseph was much beloved by his father, and on that account was hated by his brethren.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:17
verses.text: There was this further cause for their aversion, that by frequent dreams of his it seemed to be indicated that he would be greater than all of them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:18
verses.text: Accordingly, having been sent by his father to inspect the flocks and pay a visit to his brothers, there seemed to them a fitting opportunity for doing him harm.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:19
verses.text: For, on seeing their brother, they took counsel to slay him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:20
verses.text: But Reuben, whose mind shuddered at the contemplation of such a crime, opposing their plan, Joseph was let down into a well.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:21
verses.text: Afterwards, by the persuasions of Judah, they were brought to milder measures, and sold him to merchants, who were on their way to Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 10:22
verses.text: And by them he was delivered to Petifra, a governor of Pharaoh.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:2
verses.text: About this same time, Judah, the son of Jacob, took in marriage Sava, a woman of Canaan.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:3
verses.text: By her he had three sons,—Her, Onan, and Sela.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:4
verses.text: Her was allied by concubinage to Thamar.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:5
verses.text: On his death, Onan took his brother's wife; and he is related to have been destroyed by God, because he spilled his seed upon the earth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:6
verses.text: Then Thamar, assuming the garb of a harlot, united with her brother-in-law, and bore him two sons.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:7
verses.text: But when she brought them forth, there was this remarkable fact, that, when on one of the boys being born, the midwife had bound his hand with a scarlet thread to indicate which of them was born first, he, drawing back again into the womb of his mother, was born the last boy of the two.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:8
verses.text: The names of Fares and Zarah were given to the children.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:9
verses.text: But Joseph, being kindly treated by the royal governor who had obtained him for a sum of money, and having been made manager of his house and family, had drawn the eyes of his master's wife upon himself through his remarkable beauty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:10
verses.text: And as she was madly laboring under that base passion, she made advances to him oftener than once, and when he would not yield to her desires, she disgraced him by the imputation of a false crime, and complained to her husband that he had made an attempt upon her virtue.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:11
verses.text: Accordingly, Joseph was thrown into prison.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:12
verses.text: There were in the same place of confinement two of the king's servants, who made known their dreams to Joseph, and he, interpreting these as bearing upon the future, declared that one of them would be put to death, and the other would be pardoned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:13
verses.text: And so it came to pass.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:14
verses.text: Well, after the lapse of two years, the king also had a dream.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:15
verses.text: And when this could not be explained by the wise men among the Egyptians, that servant of the king who was liberated from prison informs the king that Joseph was a wonderful interpreter of dreams.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:16
verses.text: Accordingly, Joseph was brought out of prison, and interpreted to the king his dream, to this effect, that, for the next seven years, there would be the greatest fertility in the land; but in those that followed, famine.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:17
verses.text: The king being alarmed by this terror, and seeing that there was a divine spirit in Joseph, set him over the department of food-supply, and made him equal with himself in the government.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:18
verses.text: Then Joseph, while corn was abundant throughout all Egypt, gathered together an immense quantity, and, by increasing the number of granaries, took measures against the future famine.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:19
verses.text: At that time, the hope and safety of Egypt were placed in him alone.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:20
verses.text: About the same period, Aseneh bore him two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 11:21
verses.text: He himself, when he received the chief power from the king, was thirty years old; for he was sold by his brothers when he was seventeen years of age.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:2
verses.text: In the mean time, affairs having been well settled in Egypt to meet the famine, a grievous want of corn began to distress the world.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:3
verses.text: Jacob, constrained by this necessity, sent his sons into Egypt, keeping only Benjamin with himself at home.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:4
verses.text: Joseph, then, being at the head of affairs, and having complete power over the corn-supplies, his brothers come to him, and pay the same honor to him as to a king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:5
verses.text: He, when he saw them, craftily concealed his recognition of them, and accused them of having come as enemies, subtly to spy out the land.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:6
verses.text: But he was annoyed that he did not see among them his brother Benjamin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:7
verses.text: Matters, then, are brought to this point, that they promised he should be present, specially that he might be asked whether they had entered Egypt for the purpose of spying out the land.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:8
verses.text: In order to secure the fulfillment of this promise, Symeon was retained as hostage, while to them corn was given freely.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:9
verses.text: Accordingly, they returned, bringing Benjamin with them as had been arranged.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:10
verses.text: Then Joseph made himself known to his brothers to the shame of these evil-deservers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:11
verses.text: Thus, he sent them home again, laden with corn, and presented with many gifts, forewarning them that there were still five years of famine to come, and advising them to come down with their father, their children, and their whole connections to Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:12
verses.text: So Jacob went down to Egypt, to the great joy of the Egyptians and of the king himself, while he was tenderly welcomed by his son.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:13
verses.text: That took place in the hundred and thirtieth year of the life of Jacob, and one thousand three hundred and sixty years after the deluge.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:14
verses.text: But from the time when Abraham settled in the land of the Canaanites, to that when Jacob entered Egypt, there are to be reckoned two hundred and fifteen years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:15
verses.text: After this, Jacob, in the seventeenth year of his residence in Egypt, suffering severely from illness, entreated Joseph to see his remains placed in the tomb.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:16
verses.text: Then Joseph presented his sons to be blessed; and when this had been done, but so that he set the younger before the elder as to the value of the blessing given, Jacob then blessed all his sons in order.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:17
verses.text: He died at the age of one hundred and forty-seven years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:18
verses.text: His funeral was of a most imposing character, and Joseph laid his remains in the tomb of his fathers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:19
verses.text: He continued to treat his brothers with kindness, although, after the death of their father, they felt alarmed from a consciousness of the wrong they had done.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 12:20
verses.text: Joseph himself died in his one hundred and tenth year.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:2
verses.text: It is almost incredible to relate how the Hebrews who had come down into Egypt so soon increased in numbers, and filled Egypt with their numerous descendants.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:3
verses.text: But on the death of the king, who kindly cherished them on account of the services of Joseph, they were kept down by the government of the succeeding kings.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:4
verses.text: For both the heavy labor of building cities was laid upon them, and because their abounding numbers were now feared, lest some day they should secure their independence by arms, they were compelled by a royal edict to drown their newly-born male children.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:5
verses.text: And no permission was granted to evade this cruel order.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:6
verses.text: Well, at that time, the daughter of Pharaoh found an infant in the river, and caused it to be brought up as her own son, giving the boy the name of Moses.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:7
verses.text: This Moses, when he had come to manhood, saw a Hebrew being assaulted by an Egyptian; and, filled with sorrow at the sight, he delivered his brother from injury, and killed the Egyptian with a stone.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:8
verses.text: Soon after, fearing punishment on account of what he had done, he fled into the land of Midian, and, taking up his abode with Jothor the priest of that district, he received his daughter Sepphora in marriage, who bore him two sons, Gersam and Eliezer.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:9
verses.text: At this epoch lived Job, who had acquired both the knowledge of God and all righteousness simply from the law of nature.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:10
verses.text: He was exceedingly rich, and on that account all the more illustrious, because he was neither corrupted by that wealth while it remained entire, nor perverted by it when it was lost.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:11
verses.text: For, when, through the agency of the devil, he was stripped of his goods, deprived of his children, and finally covered in his own person with terrible boils, he could not be broken down, so as, from impatience of his sufferings, in any way, to commit sin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 13:12
verses.text: At length he obtained the reward of the divine approval, and being restored to health, he got back doubled all that he had lost.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:2
verses.text: But the Hebrews, oppressed by the multiplied evils of slavery, directed their complaints to heaven, and cherished the hope of assistance from God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:3
verses.text: Then, as Moses was feeding his sheep, suddenly a bush appeared to him burning, but, what was surprising, the flames did it no harm.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:4
verses.text: Astonished at such an extraordinary sight, he drew nearer to the bush, and immediately God spoke to him in words to this effect, that he was the Lord of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and that he desired that their descendants, who were kept down under the tyranny of the Egyptians, should be delivered from their sufferings, and that he, therefore, should go to the king of Egypt, and present himself as a leader for restoring them to liberty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:5
verses.text: When he hesitated, God strengthened him with power, and imparted to him the gift of working miracles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:6
verses.text: Thus Moses, going into Egypt, after he had first performed miracles in the presence of his own people, and having associated his brother Aaron with him, went to the king, declaring that he had been sent by God, and that he now told him in the words of God to let the Hebrew people go.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:7
verses.text: But the king, affirming that he did not know the Lord, refused to obey the command addressed to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:8
verses.text: And when Moses, in proof that the orders he issued were from God, changed his rod into a serpent, and soon after convened all the water into blood, while he filled the whole land with frogs, as the Chaldaeans were doing similar things, the king declared that the wonders performed by Moses were simply due to the arts of magic, and not to the power of God, until the land was covered with stinging insects brought over it, when the Chaldaeans confessed that this was done by the divine majesty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:9
verses.text: Then the king, constrained by his sufferings, called to him Moses and Aaron, and gave the people liberty to depart, provided that the calamity brought upon the kingdom were removed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:10
verses.text: But, after the suffering was put an end to, his mind, having no control over itself returned to its former state, and did not allow the Israelites to depart, as had been agreed upon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 14:11
verses.text: Finally, however, he was broken down and conquered by the ten plagues which were sent upon his person and his kingdom.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:2
verses.text: But on the day before the people went out of Egypt, being as yet unacquainted with dates, they were instructed by the command of God to acknowledge that month which was then passing by as the first of all months; and were told that the sacrifice of the day was to be solemnly and regularly offered in coming ages, so that, on the fourteenth day of the month, a lamb without blemish, one year old, should be slain as a victim, and that the door-posts should be sprinkled with its blood; that its flesh was wholly to be eaten, but not a bone of it was to be broken; that they should abstain from what was leavened for seven days, using only unleavened bread; and that they should hand down the observance to their posterity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:3
verses.text: Thus the people went forth rich, both by their own wealth, and still more by the spoils of Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:4
verses.text: Their number had grown from those seventy-five Hebrews, who had first gone down into Egypt, to six hundred thousand men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:5
verses.text: Now, there had elapsed from the time when Abraham first reached the land of the Canaanites a period of four hundred and thirty years, but from the deluge a period of five hundred and seventy-five years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:6
verses.text: Well, as they went forth in haste, a pillar of cloud by day, and a pillar of fire by night, marched before them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:7
verses.text: But since, owing to the fact that the gulf of the Red Sea lay between, the way led by the land of the Philistines, in order that an opportunity might not afterwards be offered to the Hebrews, shrinking from the desert, of returning into Egypt by a well-known road through a continuous land-journey, by the command of God they turned aside, and journeyed towards the Red Sea, where they stopped and pitched their camp.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:8
verses.text: When it was announced to the king that the Hebrew people, through mistaking the road, had come to have the sea right before them, and that they had no means of escape since the deep would prevent them, vexed and furious that so many thousand men should escape from his kingdom and power, he hastily led forth his army.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:9
verses.text: And already the arms, and standards, and the lines drawn up in the widespreading plains were visible, when, as the Hebrews were in a state of terror, and gazing up to heaven, Moses being so instructed by God, struck the sea with his rod, and divided it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:10
verses.text: Thus a road was opened to the people as on firm land, the waters giving way on both sides.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 15:11
verses.text: Nor did the king of Egypt hesitate to follow the Israelites going forward, for he entered the sea where it had opened; and, as the waters speedily came together again, he, with all his host, was destroyed.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:2
verses.text: Then Moses, exulting in the safety of his own people, and in the destruction of the enemy, by such a miracle, sang a song of praise to God, and the whole multitude, both of males and females, took part in it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:3
verses.text: But, after they had entered the desert, and advanced a journey of three days, want of water distressed them; and, when it was found, it proved of no use on  account of its bitterness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:4
verses.text: And then for the first time the stubbornness of the impatient people showed itself, and burst forth against Moses; when, as instructed by God, he cast some wood into the waters, and its power was such that it rendered the taste of the fluid sweet.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:5
verses.text: Thence advancing, the multitude found at Elim twelve fountains of waters, with seventy palm-trees, and there they encamped.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:6
verses.text: Again the people, complaining of famine, heaped reproaches upon Moses, and longed for the slavery of Egypt, accompanied as it was with abundance to please their appetite, when a flock of quails was divinely sent, and filled the camp.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:7
verses.text: Besides, on the following day, those who had gone forth from the camp perceived that the ground was covered with a sort of pods, the appearance of which was like a coriander-seed of snowy whiteness, as we often see the earth in the winter months covered with the hoar-frost that has been spread over it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:8
verses.text: Then the people were informed, through Moses, that this bread had been sent them by the gift of God; that every one should gather in vessels prepared for the purpose only so much of it as would be sufficient for each, according to their number, during one day; but that on the sixth day they should gather double, because it was not lawful to collect it on the Sabbath.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:9
verses.text: The people, however, as they were never prone to obedience, did not, in accordance with human nature, restrain their desires, providing in their stores not merely for one, but also for the following day.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:10
verses.text: But that which was thus laid up swarmed with worms, while its fetid odor was dreadful, yet that which was laid up on the sixth day with a view to the Sabbath remained quite untainted.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:11
verses.text: The Hebrews made use of this food for forty years; its taste was very like that of honey; and its name is handed down as being manna.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 16:12
verses.text: Moreover, as an abiding witness to the divine gift, Moses is related to have laid up a full gomer of it in a golden vessel.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:2
verses.text: The people going on from thence, and being again tried with want of water, hardly restrained themselves from destroying their leader.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:3
verses.text: Then Moses, under divine orders, striking with his rod the rock at the place which is called Horeb, brought forth an abundant supply of water.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:4
verses.text: But when they came to Raphidin, the Amalekites destroyed numbers of the people by their attacks.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:5
verses.text: Moses, leading out his men to battle, placed Joshua at the head of the army; and, in company with Aaron and Hur, was himself simply to be a spectator of the fight, while, at the same time, for the purpose of praying to the Lord, he went up to the top of a mountain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:6
verses.text: But when the armies had met with doubtful issue, through the prayers of Moses, Joshua slew the enemy until nightfall.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:7
verses.text: At the same time, Jothor, Moses' father-in-law, with his daughter Sepphora (who, having been married to Moses, had remained at home when her husband went into Egypt), and his children, having learned the things which were being done by Moses, came to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:8
verses.text: By his advice Moses divided the people into various ranks; and, setting tribunes, centurions, and decurions over them, thus furnished a mode of discipline and order to posterity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:9
verses.text: Jothor then returned to his own country, while the Israelites came on to Mount Sinai.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:10
verses.text: There Moses was admonished by the Lord that the people should be sanctified, since they were to hearken to the words of God; and that was carefully seen to.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:11
verses.text: But when God rested on the mountain, the air was shaken with the loud sounds of trumpets, and thick clouds rolled around with frequent flashes of lightning.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:12
verses.text: But Moses and Aaron were on the top of the mountain beside the Lord, while the people stood around the bottom of the mountain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:13
verses.text: Thus a law was given, manifold and full of the words of God, and frequently repeated; but if any one is desirous of knowing particulars regarding it, he must consult the original, as we here only briefly touch upon it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 17:14
verses.text: "There shall not be," said God, "any strange gods among you, but ye shall worship me alone; thou shalt not make to time any idol; thou shalt not take the name of thy God in vain; thou shalt do no work upon the Sabbath; honor thy father and thy mother; thou shalt not kill; thou shalt not commit adultery; thou shalt not steal; thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbor; thou shalt not covet anything belonging to thy neighbor".

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:2
verses.text: These things being said by God, while the trumpets uttered their voices, the lamps blazed, and smoke covered the mountain, the people trembled from terror; and begged of Moses that God should speak to him alone, and that he would report to the people what he thus heard.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:3
verses.text: Now, the commandments of God to Moses were as follows: A Hebrew servant purchased with money shall serve six years, and after that he shall be free; but his ear shall be bored, should he willingly remain in slavery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:4
verses.text: Whosoever slays a man shall be put to death;  he who does so unwittingly shall in due form be banished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:5
verses.text: Whosoever shall beat his father or his mother, and utter evil sayings against them, shall suffer death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:6
verses.text: If any one sell a Hebrew who has been stolen, he shall be put to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:7
verses.text: If any one strike his own man-servant or maidservant, and he or she die of the blow, he shall be put on his trial for doing so.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:8
verses.text: If any one cause a woman to miscarry, he shall be put to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:9
verses.text: If any one knock out the eye or the tooth of his servant, that servant shall receive his liberty in due form.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:10
verses.text: If a bull kill a man, it shall be stoned; and if its master, knowing the vicious temper of the animal, did not take precautions in connection with it, he also shall be stoned, or shall redeem himself by a price as large as the accuser shall demand.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:11
verses.text: If a bull kill a servant, money to the amount of thirty double-drachmas shall be paid to his master.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:12
verses.text: If any one does not cover up a pit which has been dug, and an animal fall into that pit, he shall pay the price of the animal to its master.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:13
verses.text: If a bull kill the bull of another man, the animal shall be sold, and the two masters shall share the price; they shall also divide the animal that has been killed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:14
verses.text: But if a master, knowing the vicious temper of the bull, did not take precautions in connection with it, he shall give up the bull.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:15
verses.text: If any one steals a calf, he shall restore five; if he steals a sheep, the penalty shall be fourfold; and if the animals be found alive in the hands of him who drove them off, he shall restore double.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:16
verses.text: It shall be lawful to kill a thief by night, but not one by day.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:17
verses.text: If the cattle of any one has eaten up the corn of another, the master of the cattle shall restore what has been destroyed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:18
verses.text: If a deposit disappears, he, in whose hands it was deposited, shall swear that he has not been guilty of any deceit.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:19
verses.text: A thief who is caught shall pay double.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:20
verses.text: An animal given in trust, if devoured by a wild beast, shall not be made good.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:21
verses.text: If any one defile a virgin not yet betrothed, he shall bestow a dowry on the girl, and thus take her to wife; but, if the father of the girl shall refuse to give her in marriage, then the ravisher shall give her a dowry.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:22
verses.text: If any one shall join himself to a beast, he shall be put to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:23
verses.text: Let him who sacrifices to idols perish.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:24
verses.text: The widow and orphan are not to be oppressed; the poor debtor is not to be hardly treated, nor is usury to be demanded: the garment of the poor is not to be taken as a pledge.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:25
verses.text: A ruler of the people is not to be evil spoken of.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:26
verses.text: All the first-born are to be offered to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:27
verses.text: Flesh taken from a wild beast is not to be eaten.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:28
verses.text: Agreements to bear false witness, or for any evil purpose, are not to be made.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:29
verses.text: Thou shalt not pass by any animal of thine enemy which has strayed, but shalt bring it back.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:30
verses.text: If you find an animal of your enemy fallen down under a burden, it will be your duty to raise it up.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:31
verses.text: Thou shalt not slay the innocent and the righteous.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:32
verses.text: Thou shalt not justify the wicked for rewards.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:33
verses.text: Gifts are not to be accepted.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:34
verses.text: A stranger is to be kindly treated.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:35
verses.text: Work is to be done on six days: rest is to be taken on the Sabbath.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 18:36
verses.text: The crops of the seventh year are not to be reaped, but are to be left for the poor and needy.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:2
verses.text: Moses reported these words of God to the people, and placed an altar of twelve stones at the foot of the mountain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:3
verses.text: Then he again ascended the mountain on which the Lord had taken his place, bringing with him Aaron, Nabad, and seventy of the elders.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:4
verses.text: But these were not able to look upon the Lord; nevertheless, they saw the place in which God stood, whose form is related to have been wonderful, and his splendor glorious.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:5
verses.text: Now, Moses, having been called by God, entered the inner cloud which had gathered round about God, and is related to have remained there forty days and forty nights.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:6
verses.text: During this time, he was taught in the words of God about building the tabernacle and the ark, and about the ritual of sacrifice-things which I, as they were obviously told at great length, have not thought proper to be inserted in such a concise work as the present.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:7
verses.text: But as Moses stayed away a long time, since he spent forty days in the presence of the Lord, the people, despairing of his return, compelled Aaron to construct images.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:8
verses.text: Then, out of metals which had been melted together, there came forth the head of a calf.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:9
verses.text: The people, unmindful of God, having offered sacrifices to this, and given themselves up to eating and drinking, God, looking upon these things, would in his righteous indignation, have destroyed the wicked people, had he not been entreated by Moses' not to do so.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:10
verses.text: But Moses, on his return, bringing down the two tables of stone which had been written by the hand of God, and seeing the people devoted to luxury and sacrilege, broke the tables, thinking the nation unworthy of having the law of the Lord delivered to them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:11
verses.text: He then called around himself the Levites, who had been assailed with many insults, and commanded them to smite the people with drawn swords.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:12
verses.text: In this onset twenty-three thousand men are said to have been slain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:13
verses.text: Then Moses set up the tabernacle outside the camp; and, as often  as he entered it, the pillar of cloud was observed to stand before the door; and God spoke, face to face, with Moses.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:14
verses.text: But when Moses entreated that he might see the Lord in his peculiar majesty, he was answered that the form of God could not be seen by mortal eyes; yet it was allowed to see his back parts; and the tables which Moses had formerly broken were constructed afresh.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:15
verses.text: And Moses is reported, during this conference with God, to have stayed forty days with the Lord.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:16
verses.text: Moreover, when he descended from the mountain, bringing with him the tables, his face shone with so great brightness, that the people were not able to look upon him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:17
verses.text: It was arranged, therefore, that when he was to make known to them the commands of God, he covered his face with a veil, and thus spoke to the people in the words of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:18
verses.text: In this part of the history an account is given of the tabernacle, and the building of its inner parts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:19
verses.text: Which having been finished, the cloud descended from above, and so overshadowed the tabernacle that it prevented Moses himself from entering.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 19:20
verses.text: These are the principal matters contained in the two books of Genesis and Exodus.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:2
verses.text: Then follows the book of Leviticus, in which the precepts bearing upon sacrifice are set forth; commandments also are added to the law formerly given; and almost the whole is full of instructions connected with the priests.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:3
verses.text: If any one wishes to become acquainted with these, he will obtain fuller information from that source.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:4
verses.text: For we, keeping within the limits of the work undertaken, touch upon the history only.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:5
verses.text: The tribe of Levi, then, being set apart for the priesthood, the rest of the tribes were numbered, and were found to amount to six hundred and three thousand five hundred persons.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:6
verses.text: When, therefore, the people made use of the manna for food, as we have related above, even amid so many and so great kindnesses of God, showing themselves, as ever, ungrateful, they longed after the worthless viands to which they had been accustomed in Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:7
verses.text: Then the Lord brought an enormous supply of quails into the camp; and as they were eagerly tearing these to pieces, as soon as their lips touched the flesh, they perished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:8
verses.text: There was indeed on that day a great destruction in the camp, so that twenty and three thousand men are said to have died.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:9
verses.text: Thus the people were punished by the very food which they desired.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:10
verses.text: Thence the company went forward, and came to Faran; and Moses was instructed by the Lord that the land was now near, the possession of which the Lord had promised them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:11
verses.text: Spies, accordingly, having been sent into it, they report that it was a land blessed with all abundance, but that the nations were powerful, and the towns fortified with immense walls.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:12
verses.text: When this was made known to the people, fear seized the minds of all; and to such a pitch of wickedness did they come, that, despising the authority of Moses, they prepared to appoint for themselves a leader, under whose guidance they might return to Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:13
verses.text: Then Joshua and Caleb, who had been of the number of the spies, rent their garments with tears, and implored the people not to believe the spies relating such terrors; for that they themselves had been with them, and had found nothing dreadful in that country; and that it behooved them to trust the promises of God, that these enemies would rather become their prey than prove their destruction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:14
verses.text: But that stiff-necked race, setting themselves against every good advice, rushed upon them to destroy them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 20:15
verses.text: And the Lord, angry on account of these things, exposed a part of the people to be slain by the enemy, while the spies were slain for having excited fear among the people.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:2
verses.text: There followed the revolt of those, who, with Dathan and Abiron as leaders, endeavored to set themselves up against Moses and Aaron; but the earth, opening, swallowed them alive.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:3
verses.text: And not long after, a revolt of the whole people arose against Moses and Aaron, so that they rushed into the tabernacle, which it was not lawful for any but the priests to enter.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:4
verses.text: Then truly death mowed them down in heaps; and all would have perished in a moment, had not the Lord, appeased by the prayers of Moses, turned aside the disaster.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:5
verses.text: Nevertheless, the number of those slain amounted to seven hundred and fourteen thousand.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:6
verses.text: And not long after, as had already often happened, a revolt of the people arose on account of the want of water.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:7
verses.text: Then Moses, instructed by God to strike the rock with his rod, with a kind of trial new familiar to him, since he had already done that before, struck the rock once and again, and thus water flowed out of it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:8
verses.text: In regard, however, to this point, Moses is said to have been reproved by God, that, through want of faith, he did not bring out the water except by repeated blows; in fact, on account of this transgression, he did not enter the land promised to him, as I shall show farther on.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:9
verses.text: Moses, then, moving away from that place, as he was preparing to lead his  company along by the borders of Edom, sent ambassadors to the king to beg liberty to pass by; for he thought it right to abstain from war on account of the connection by blood; for that nation was descended from Esau.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:10
verses.text: But the king despised the suppliants, and refused them liberty to pass by, being ready to contend in arms.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:11
verses.text: Then Moses directed his march towards the mountain, Or, keeping clear of the forbidden road, that he might not furnish any cause of war between those related by blood, and on that route he destroyed the king of the nation of the Canaanites.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:12
verses.text: He smote also Seon the king of the Amorites, and possessed himself of all their towns: he conquered, too, Basan and Balac.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:13
verses.text: He pitched his camp beyond Jordan, not far from Jericho.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:14
verses.text: Then a battle took place against the Midianites, and they were conquered and subdued.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:15
verses.text: Moses died, after he had ruled the people forty years in the wilderness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:16
verses.text: But the Hebrews are said to have remained in the wilderness for so long a time, with this view, until all those who had not believed the words of God perished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:17
verses.text: For, except Joshua and Caleb, not one of those who were more than twenty years old on leaving Egypt passed over Jordan.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:18
verses.text: That Moses himself only saw the promised land, and did not reach it, is ascribed to his sin, because, at that time when he was ordered to strike the rock, and bring forth water, he doubted, even after so many proofs of his miraculous power.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:19
verses.text: He died in the one hundred and twentieth year of his age.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 21:20
verses.text: Nothing is known concerning the place of his burial.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:2
verses.text: After the death of Moses, the chief power passed into the hands of Joshua the son of Nun, for Moses had appointed him his successor, being a man very like himself in the good qualities which he displayed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:3
verses.text: Now, at the commencement of his rule, he sent messengers through the camp to instruct the people to make ready supplies of corn, and announces that they should march on the third day.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:4
verses.text: But the river Jordan, a very powerful stream, hindered their crossing, because they did not have a supply of vessels for the occasion, and the stream could not be crossed by fords, as it was then rushing on in full flood.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:5
verses.text: He, therefore, orders the ark to be carried forward by the priests, and that they should take their stand against the current of the river.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:6
verses.text: On this being done, Jordan is said to have been divided, and thus the army was led over on dry ground.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:7
verses.text: There was in these places a town called Jericho, fortified with very strong walls, and not easy to be taken, either by storm or blockade.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:8
verses.text: But Joshua, putting his trust in God, did not attack the city either by arms or force; he simply ordered the ark of God to be carried round the walls, while the priests walked before the ark, and sounded trumpets.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:9
verses.text: But when the ark had been carried round seven times, the walls and the towers fell; and the city was plundered and burnt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:10
verses.text: Then Joshua is said to have addressed the Lord, and to have called down a curse upon any one who should attempt to restore the town which had thus by divine help been demolished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:11
verses.text: Next, the army was led against Geth, and an ambuscade having been placed behind the city, Joshua, pretending fear, fled before the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:12
verses.text: On seeing this, those who were in the town, opening the gates, began to press upon the enemy giving way.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 22:13
verses.text: Thus, the men who were in ambush took the city, and all the inhabitants were slain, without one escaping: the king also was taken, and suffered capital punishment.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:2
verses.text: When this became known to the kings of the neighboring nations, they made a warlike alliance to put down the Hebrews by arms.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:3
verses.text: But the Gibeonites, a powerful nation with a wealthy city, spontaneously yielded to the Hebrews, promising to do what they were ordered, and were received under protection, while they were told to bring in wood and water.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:4
verses.text: But their surrender had roused the resentment of the kings of the nearest cities.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:5
verses.text: Accordingly, moving up their troops, they surround with a blockade their town, which was called Gabaoth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:6
verses.text: The townspeople, therefore, in their distress, send messengers to Joshua, that he would help them in their state of siege.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:7
verses.text: Accordingly, he by a forced march came upon the enemy at unawares, and many thousands of them were completely destroyed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:8
verses.text: When day failed the victors, and it seemed that night would furnish protection to the vanquished, the Hebrew general, through the power of his faith, kept off the night, and the day continued, so that there was no means of escape for the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:9
verses.text: Five kings who were taken suffered death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:10
