verses.text: By the same attack, neighboring cities also were brought under the power of Joshua, and their kings were cut off.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:11
verses.text: But as it was not my design, studious as I am of brevity, to follow out all these things in order, I only carefully observe this, that twenty-nine kingdoms were brought under the yoke of the Hebrews, and that their territory was distributed among eleven tribes, to man after man.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:12
verses.text: For to the Levites, who had been set apart for the priesthood, no portion was given, in order that they might the more freely serve God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:13
verses.text: I desire not, in silence, to pass over the example thus set, but I would earnestly bring it forward as well worthy of being read by the ministers of the Church.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:14
verses.text: For these seem to me not only unmindful of this precept, but even utterly ignorant of it—such a lust for possessing has, in this age, seized, like an incurable disease, upon their minds.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:15
verses.text: They gape upon possessions; they cultivate estates; they repose upon gold; they buy and sell; they study gain by every possible means.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:16
verses.text: And even, if any of them seem to have a better aim in life, neither possessing nor trading, still (what is much more disgraceful) remaining inactive, they look for gifts, and have corrupted the whole glory of life by their mercenary dispositions, while they present an appearance of sanctity, as if even that might be made a source of gain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:17
verses.text: But I have gone farther than I intended in expressing my loathing and disgust over the character of our times; and I hasten to return to the subject in hand.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:18
verses.text: The vanquished territory, then, as I have already said, having been divided among the tribes, the Hebrews enjoyed profound peace; their neighbors, being terrified by war, did not venture to attempt hostilities against those distinguished by so many victories.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:19
verses.text: At the same period died Joshua in the hundred and tenth year of his age.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:20
verses.text: I do not express any definite opinion as to the length of time he ruled: the prevalent view, however, is, that he was at the head of the Hebrew affairs during twenty-seven years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 23:21
verses.text: If this were so, then three thousand eight hundred and eighty-four years had elapsed from the beginning of the world to his death.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:2
verses.text: After the death of Joshua, the people acted without a leader.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:3
verses.text: But a necessity of making war with the Canaanites having arisen, Judah was appointed as general in the war.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:4
verses.text: Under his guidance, matters were successfully conducted: there was the greatest tranquillity both at home and abroad: the people ruled over the nations which had either been subdued or received under terms of surrender.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:5
verses.text: Then, as almost always happens in a time of prosperity, becoming unmindful of morals and discipline, they began to contract marriages from among the conquered, and by and by to adopt foreign customs, yea, even in a sacrilegious manner to offer sacrifice to idols: so pernicious is all alliance with foreigners.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:6
verses.text: God, foreseeing these things long before, had, by a wholesome precept enjoined upon the Hebrews to give over the conquered nations to utter destruction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:7
verses.text: But the people, through lust for power, preferred (to their own ruin) to rule over those who were conquered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:8
verses.text: Accordingly, when, forsaking God, they worshiped idols, they were deprived of the divine assistance, and, being vanquished and subdued by the king of Mesopotamia, they paid the penalty of eight years' captivity, until, with Gothoniel as their leader, they were restored to liberty, and enjoyed independence for fifty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:9
verses.text: Then again, corrupted by the evil effect of a lengthened peace, they began to sacrifice to idols.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:10
verses.text: And speedily did retribution fall upon them thus sinning.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:11
verses.text: Conquered by Eglon, king of the Moabites, they served him eighteen years, until, by a divine impulse, Aod slew the enemies' king by a stratagem, and, gathering together a hasty army, restored them to liberty by force of arms.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:12
verses.text: The same man ruled the Hebrews in peace for forty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:13
verses.text: To him Semigar succeeded, and he, engaging in battle with the Philistines, secured a decisive victory.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:14
verses.text: But again, the king of the Canaanites, Jabin by name, subdued the Hebrews who were once more serving idols, and exercised over them a grievous tyranny for twenty years, until Deborah, a woman, restored them to their former condition.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:15
verses.text: They had to such a degree lost confidence in their generals, that they were now protected by means of a woman.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:16
verses.text: But it is worthy of notice, that this form of deliverance was arranged beforehand, as a type of the Church, by whose aid captivity to the devil is escaped.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:17
verses.text: The Hebrews were forty years under this leader or judge.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:18
verses.text: And being again delivered over to the Midianites for their sins, they were kept under hard rule; and, being afflicted by the evils of slavery, they implored the divine help.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:19
verses.text: Thus always when in prosperity they were unmindful of the kindnesses of heaven, and prayed to idols; but in adversity they cried to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:20
verses.text: Wherefore, as often as I reflect that those people who lay under so many obligations to the goodness of God, being chastised with so many disasters when they sinned, and experiencing both the mercy and the severity of God, yet were by no means rendered better, and that, though they always obtained pardon for their transgressions, yet they as constantly sinned again after being pardoned, it can appear nothing wonderful that Christ when he came was not received by them, since already, from the beginning, they were found so often rebelling against the Lord.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 24:21
verses.text: It is, in fact, far more wonderful that the clemency of God never failed them when they sinned, if only they called upon his name.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:2
verses.text: Accordingly, when the Midianites, as we have related above, ruled over them, they turned to the Lord, imploring his wonted tender mercy, and obtained it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:3
verses.text: There was then among the Hebrews one Gideon by name, a righteous man who was dear and acceptable to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:4
verses.text: The angel stood by him as he was returning home from the harvest-field, and said unto him, "The Lord is with thee, thou mighty man of valor".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:5
verses.text: But he in a humble voice complained that the Lord was not with him, because captivity pressed sore upon his people, and he remembered with tears the miracles wrought by the Lord, who had brought them out of the land of Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:6
verses.text: Then the angel said, "Go, in this spirit in which you have spoken, and deliver the people from captivity".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:7
verses.text: But he declared that he could not, with his feeble strength, since he was a man of very small importance, undertake such a heavy task.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:8
verses.text: The angel, however, persisted in urging him not to doubt that those things could be done which the Lord said.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:9
verses.text: So then, having offered sacrifice, and overthrown the altar which the Midianites had consecrated to the image of Baal, he went to his own people, and pitched his camp near the camp of the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:10
verses.text: But the nation of the Amalekites had also joined themselves to the Midianites, while Gideon had not gathered more than an army of thirty-two thousand men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:11
verses.text: But before the battle began, God said to him that this was a larger number than he wished him to lead forth to the conflict; that, if he did make use of so many, the Hebrews would, in accordance with their usual wickedness ascribe the result of the fight, not to God, but to their own bravery; he should therefore furnish an opportunity of leaving to those who desired to do so.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:12
verses.text: When this was made known to the people, twenty and two thousand left the camp.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:13
verses.text: But of the ten thousand who had remained, Gideon, as instructed by God, did not retain more than three hundred: the rest he dismissed from the field.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:14
verses.text: Thus, entering the camp of the enemy in the middle watch of the night, and having ordered all his men to sound their trumpets, he caused great terror to the enemy; and no one had courage to resist; but they made off in a disgraceful flight wherever they could.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:15
verses.text: The Hebrews, however, meeting them in every direction, cut the fugitives to pieces.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:16
verses.text: Gideon pursued the kings beyond Jordan, and having captured them, gave them over to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:17
verses.text: In that battle, a hundred and twenty thousand of the enemy are said to have been slain, and fifteen thousand captured.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:18
verses.text: Then, by universal consent, a proposal was made to Gideon that he should be king of the people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:19
verses.text: But he rejected this proposal, and preferred rather to live on equal terms with his fellow-citizens than to be their ruler.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 25:20
verses.text: Having, therefore, escaped from their captivity, which had pressed upon the people for seven years, they now enjoyed peace for a period of forty years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:2
verses.text: But on the death of Gideon, his son Abimelech, whose mother was a concubine, having slain his brothers with the concurrence of a multitude of wicked men, and especially by the help of the chief men among the Shechemites, took possession of the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:3
verses.text: And he, being harassed by civil strife, while he pressed hard upon his people by war, attempted to storm a certain tower, into which they, after losing the town, had betaken themselves by flight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:4
verses.text: But, as he approached the place without sufficient caution, he was slain by a stone which a woman threw, after holding the government for three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:5
verses.text: To him succeeded Thola, who reigned two and twenty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:6
verses.text: After him came Jair; and after he had held the chief place for a like period of twenty-two years, the people, forsaking God, gave themselves up to idols.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:7
verses.text: On this account, the Israelites were subdued by the Philistines and Ammonites, and remained under their power for eighteen years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:8
verses.text: At the end of this period, they began to call upon God; but the divine answer to them was that they should rather invoke the aid of their images, for that he would no longer extend his mercy to those who had been so ungrateful.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:9
verses.text: But they with tears confessed their fault, and implored forgiveness; while, throwing away their idols, and earnestly calling upon God, they obtained the divine compassion, though it had been at first refused.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:10
verses.text: Accordingly, under Jephtha as general, they assembled in great numbers for the purpose of recovering their liberty by arms, having first sent ambassadors to King Ammon, begging that, content with his own territories, he should keep from warring against them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:11
verses.text: But he, far from declining battle, at once drew up his army.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:12
verses.text: Then Jephtha, before the signal for battle was given, is said to have vowed that, if he obtained the victory, the person who first met him as he returned home, should be offered to God as a sacrifice.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:13
verses.text: Accordingly, on the enemy being defeated, as Jephtha was returning home, his daughter met him, having joyfully gone forth with drums and dances to receive her father as a conqueror.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:14
verses.text: Then Jephtha, being overwhelmed with sorrow, rent his clothes in his affliction, and made known to his daughter the stringent  obligation of his vow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:15
verses.text: But she, with a courage not to be expected from a woman, did not refuse to die; she only begged that her life might be spared for two months, that she might before dying have the opportunity of seeing the friends of her own age.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:16
verses.text: This being done, she willingly returned to her father, and fulfilled the vow to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:17
verses.text: Jephtha held the chief power for six years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:18
verses.text: To him Esebon succeeded, and having ruled in tranquillity for seven years, then died.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 26:19
verses.text: After him, Elon the Zebulonite ruled for ten years, and Abdon also for eight years; but, as their rule was peaceful, they performed nothing which history might record.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:2
verses.text: The Israelites yet again turned to idols; and, being deprived of the divine protection, were subdued by the Philistines, and paid the penalty of their unfaithfulness by forty years of captivity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:3
verses.text: At that time, Samson is related to have been born.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:4
verses.text: His mother, after being long barren, had a vision of an angel, and was told to abstain from wine, and strong drink, and everything unclean; for that she should bear a son who would be the restorer of liberty to the Israelites, and their avenger upon their enemies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:5
verses.text: He, with unshorn locks, is said to have been possessed of marvelous strength, so much so that he tore to pieces with his hands a lion which met him in the way.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:6
verses.text: He had a wife from the Philistines, and when she, in the absence of her husband, had entered into marriage with another, he, through indignation on account of his wife being thus taken from him, wrought destruction to her nation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:7
verses.text: Trusting in God and his own strength, he openly brought disaster on those hitherto victors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:8
verses.text: For, catching three hundred foxes, he tied burning torches to their tails, and sent them into the fields of the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:9
verses.text: It so happened that at the time the harvest was ripe, and thus the fire easily caught, while the vines and olive-trees were burnt to ashes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:10
verses.text: He was thus seen to have avenged the injury done him in taking away his wife, by a great loss inflicted on the Philistines.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:11
verses.text: And they, enraged at this disaster, destroyed by fire the woman who had been the cause of so great a calamity, along with her house and her father.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:12
verses.text: But Samson, thinking himself as yet but poorly avenged, ceased not to harass the heathen race with all sorts of evil devices.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:13
verses.text: Then the Jews, being compelled to it, handed him over as a prisoner to the Philistines; but, when thus handed over, he burst his bonds and seizing the jaw-bone of an ass, which chance offered him as a weapon, he slew a thousand of his enemies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 27:14
verses.text: And, as the heat of the day grew violent, and he began to suffer from thirst, he called upon God, and water flowed forth from the bone which he held in his hand.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:2
verses.text: At that time Samson ruled over the Hebrews, the Philistines having been subdued by the prowess of a single individual.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:3
verses.text: They, therefore, sought his life by stratagem, not daring to assail him openly, and with this view they bribe his wife (whom he had received after what has been stated took place) to betray to them wherein the strength of her husband lay.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:4
verses.text: She attacked him with female blandishments; and, after he had deceived her, and staved off her purpose for a long time, she persuaded him to tell that his strength was situated in his hair.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:5
verses.text: Presently she cut off his hair stealthily while he was asleep, and thus delivered him up to the Philistines; for although he had often before been given up to them, they had not been able to hold him fast.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:6
verses.text: Then they, having put out his eyes, bound him with fetters, and cast him into prison.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:7
verses.text: But, in course of time, his hair which had been cut off began to grow again, and his strength to return with it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:8
verses.text: And now Samson, conscious of his recovered strength, was only waiting for an opportunity of righteous revenge.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:9
verses.text: The Philistines had a custom on their festival days of producing Samson as if to make a public spectacle of him, while they mocked their illustrious captive.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:10
verses.text: Accordingly, on a certain day, when they were making a feast in honor of their idol, they ordered Samson to be exhibited.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:11
verses.text: Now, the temple, in which all the people and all the princes of the Philistines feasted, rested on two pillars of remarkable size; and Samson, when brought out, was placed between these pillars.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:12
verses.text: Then he, having first called upon the Lord, seized his opportunity, and threw down the pillars.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:13
verses.text: The whole multitude was overwhelmed in the ruins of the building, and Samson himself died along with his enemies, not without having avenged himself upon them, after he had ruled the Hebrews twenty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:14
verses.text: To him Simmichar succeeded, of whom Scripture relates nothing more than that simple fact.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:15
verses.text: For I do not find that even the time when his rule came to an end is mentioned, and I see that the people was for some time without a leader.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:16
verses.text: Accordingly, when civil war arose against the tribe of Benjamin, Judah was chosen as a temporary leader in the war.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:17
verses.text: But most of those who have written about these times note that his rule was only for a single year.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:18
verses.text: On this account, many pass him by altogether, and place Eli, the priest, immediately after Samson.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 28:19
verses.text: We shall leave that point doubtful, as one not positively ascertained.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:2
verses.text: About these times, civil war, as we have said, had broken out; and the following was the cause of the tumult.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:3
verses.text: A certain Levite was on a journey along with his concubine, and, constrained by the approach of night, he took up his abode in the town of Gabaa, which was inhabited by men of Benjamin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:4
verses.text: A certain old man having kindly admitted him to hospitality, the young men of the town surrounded the guest, with the view of subjecting him to improper treatment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:5
verses.text: After being much chidden by the old man, and with difficulty dissuaded from their purpose, they at length received for their wanton sport the person of his concubine as a substitute for his own; and they thus spared the stranger, but abused her through the whole night, and only restored her on the following day.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:6
verses.text: But she (whether from the injury their vile conduct had inflicted on her, or from shame, I do not venture to assert) died on again seeing her husband.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:7
verses.text: Then the Levite, in testimony of the horrible deed, divided her members into twelve parts, and distributed them among the twelve tribes that indignation at such conduct might the more readily be excited in them all.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:8
verses.text: And when this became known to all of them, the other eleven tribes entered into a warlike confederacy against Benjamin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:9
verses.text: In this war, Judah, as we have said, was the general.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:10
verses.text: But they had bad success in the first two battles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:11
verses.text: At length, however, in the third, the Benjamites were conquered, and cut off to a man; thus the crime of a few was punished by the destruction of a multitude.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:12
verses.text: These things also are contained in the Book of Judges: the Books of Kings follow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:13
verses.text: But to me who am following the succession of the years, and the order of the dates, the history does not appear marked by strict chronological accuracy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:14
verses.text: For, since after Samson as judge, there came Semigar, and a little later the history certifies that the people lived without judges, Eli the priest is related in the Books of Kings to have also been a judge, but the Scripture has not stated how many years there were between Eli and Samson.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:15
verses.text: I see that there was some portion of time between these two, which is left in obscurity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:16
verses.text: But, from the day of the death of Joshua up to the time at which Samson died, there are reckoned four hundred and eighteen years, and from the beginning of the world, four thousand three hundred and three.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:17
verses.text: Nevertheless, I am not ignorant that others differ from this reckoning of ours; but I am at the same time conscious that I have, not without some care, set forth the order of events in the successive years (a thing hitherto left in obscurity), until I have fallen upon these times, concerning which I confess that I have my doubts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 29:18
verses.text: Now I shall go on to what remains.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:2
verses.text: The Hebrews, then, as I have narrated above, were living according to their own will, without any judge or general.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:3
verses.text: Eli was priest; and in his days Samuel was born.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:4
verses.text: His father's name was Elchana, and his mother's, Anna.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:5
verses.text: She having long been barren, is said, when she asked a child from God, to have vowed that, if it were a boy, it should be dedicated to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:6
verses.text: Accordingly, having brought forth a boy, she delivered him to Eli the priest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:7
verses.text: By and by, when he had grown up, God spoke to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:8
verses.text: He denounced wrath against Eli the priest on account of the life of his sons, who had made the priesthood of their father a means of gain to themselves, and exacted gifts from those who came to sacrifice; and, although their father is related to have often reproved them, yet his reproofs were too gentle to serve the purpose of discipline.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:9
verses.text: Well, the Philistines made an incursion into Judaea, and were met by the Israelites.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:10
verses.text: But the Hebrews, being beaten, prepare to renew the contest: they carry the ark of the Lord with them into battle, and the sons of the priests go forth with it, because he himself, being burdened with years, and afflicted with blindness, could not discharge that duty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:11
verses.text: But, when the ark was brought within sight of the enemy, terrified as if by the majesty of God's presence, they were ready to take to flight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:12
verses.text: But again recovering courage, and changing their minds (not without a divine impulse), they rush into battle with their whole strength.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:13
verses.text: The Hebrews were conquered; the ark was taken; the sons of the priest fell.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 30:14
verses.text: Eli, when the news of the calamity was brought to him, being overwhelmed with grief, breathed his last, after he had held the priesthood for twenty years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:2
verses.text: The Philistines, victorious in this prosperous battle, brought the ark of God, which had fallen into their hands, into the temple of Dagon in the town of Azotus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:3
verses.text: But the image, dedicated to a demon, fell down when the ark was brought in there; and, on their setting the idol up again  in its place, in the following night it was torn in pieces.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:4
verses.text: Then mice, springing up throughout all the country, caused by their venomous bites the death of many thousand persons.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:5
verses.text: The men of Azotus, constrained by this source of suffering, in order to escape the calamity, removed the ark to Gath.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:6
verses.text: But the people there being afflicted with the same evils, conveyed the ark to Ascalon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:7
verses.text: The inhabitants, however, of that place, the chief men of the nation having been called together, formed the design of sending back the ark to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:8
verses.text: Thus, in accordance with the opinion of the chiefs, and augurs, and priests, it was placed upon a cart, and sent back with many gifts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:9
verses.text: This remarkable thing then happened, that when they had yoked heifers to the conveyance, and had retained their calves at home, these cattle took their course, without any guide, towards Judaea, and showed no desire of returning, from affection toward their young left behind.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:10
verses.text: The rulers of the Philistines, who had followed the ark into the territory of the Hebrews, were so struck by the marvelousness of this occurrence that they performed a religious service.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:11
verses.text: But the Jews, when they saw the ark brought back, vied with each other in joyously rushing forth from the town of Betsamis to meet it, and in hurrying, exulting, and returning thanks to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:12
verses.text: Presently, the Levites, whose business it was, perform a sacrifice to God, and offer those heifers which had brought the ark.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:13
verses.text: But the ark could not be kept in the town which I have named above, and thus severe illness fell by the appointment of God, upon the whole city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 31:14
verses.text: The ark was then transferred to the town of Cariathiarim, and there it remained twenty years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:2
verses.text: At this time, Samuel the priest ruled over the Hebrews; and there being a cessation of all war, the people lived in peace.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:3
verses.text: But this tranquillity was disturbed by an invasion of the Philistines, and all ranks were in a state of terror from their consciousness of guilt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:4
verses.text: Samuel, having first offered sacrifice, and trusting in God, led his men out to battle, and the enemy being routed at the first onset, victory declared for the Hebrews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:5
verses.text: But when the fear of the enemy was thus removed, and affairs were now prosperous and peaceful, the people, changing their views for the worse, after the manner of the mob, who are always weary of what they have, and long for things of which they have had no experience, expressed a desire for the kingly name—a name greatly disliked by almost all free nations.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:6
verses.text: Yes, with an example of madness certainly very remarkable, they now preferred to exchange liberty for slavery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:7
verses.text: They, therefore, come in great numbers to Samuel, in order that, as he himself was now an old man, he might make for them a king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:8
verses.text: But he endeavored in a useful address, quietly to deter the people from their insane desire; he set forth the tyranny and haughty rule of kings, while he extolled liberty, and denounced slavery; finally, he threatened them with the divine wrath, if they should show themselves men so corrupt in mind as that, when having God as their king, they should demand for themselves a king from among men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:9
verses.text: Having spoken these and other words of a like nature to no purpose, finding that the people persisted in the determination, he consulted God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 32:10
verses.text: And God, moved by the madness of that insane nation, replied that nothing was to be refused to them asking against their own interests.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:2
verses.text: Accordingly, Saul, having been first anointed by Samuel with the sacerdotal oil, was appointed king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:3
verses.text: He was of the tribe of Benjamin, and his father's name was Kish.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:4
verses.text: He was modest in mind, and of a singularly handsome figure, so that the dignity of his person worthily corresponded to the royal dignity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:5
verses.text: But in the beginning of his reign, some portion of the people had revolted from him, refusing to acknowledge his authority, and had joined themselves to the Ammonites.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:6
verses.text: Saul, however, energetically wreaked his vengeance on these people; the enemy were conquered, and pardon was granted to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:7
verses.text: Then Saul is said to have been anointed by Samuel a second time.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:8
verses.text: Next, a bloody war arose by an invasion of the Philistines; and Saul had appointed Gilgal as the place where his army was to assemble.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:9
verses.text: As they waited there seven days for Samuel, that he might offer sacrifice to God, the people gradually dropped away owing to his delay, and the king, with unlawful presumption, presented a burnt-offering, thus taking upon him the duty of a priest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:10
verses.text: For this he was severely rebuked by Samuel, and acknowledged his sin with a penitence that was too late.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:11
verses.text: For, as a result of the king's sin, fear had pervaded the whole army.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:12
verses.text: The camp of the enemy lying at no great distance showed them how actual the danger was, and no one had the courage to think of going forth to battle: most had be-taken themselves to the marshes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:13
verses.text: For besides the want of courage on the part of those who  felt that God was alienated from them on account of the king's sin, the army was in the greatest want of iron weapons; so much so that nobody, except Saul and Jonathan his son, is said to have possessed either sword or spear.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:14
verses.text: For the Philistines, as conquerors in the former wars, had deprived the Hebrews of the use of arms, and no one had had the power of forging any weapon of war, or even making any implement for rural purposes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:15
verses.text: In these circumstances, Jonathan, with an audacious design, and with his armor-bearer as his only companion, entered the camp of the enemy, and having slain about twenty of them, spread a terror throughout the whole army.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:16
verses.text: And then, through the appointment of God, betaking themselves to flight, they neither carried out orders nor kept their ranks, but placed all the hope of safety in flight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:17
verses.text: Saul, perceiving this, hastily drew forth his men, and pursuing the fugitives, obtained a victory.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:18
verses.text: The king is said on that day to have issued a proclamation that no one should help himself to food until the enemy were destroyed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:19
verses.text: But Jonathan, knowing nothing of this prohibition, found a honey-comb, and, dipping the point of his weapon in it, ate up the honey.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:20
verses.text: When that became known to the king through the anger of God which followed, he ordered his son to be put to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:21
verses.text: But by the help of the people, he was saved from destruction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:22
verses.text: At that time, Samuel, being instructed by God, went to the king, and told him in the words of God to make war on the nation of the Amalekites, who had of old hindered the Hebrews when they were coming out of Egypt; and the prohibition was added that they should not covet any of the spoils of the conquered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:23
verses.text: Accordingly, an army was led into the territory of the enemy, the king was taken, and the nation subdued.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 33:24
verses.text: But Saul, unable to resist the magnitude of the spoil, and unmindful of the divine injunctions, ordered the booty to be saved and gathered together.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:2
verses.text: God, displeased with what had been done, spoke to Samuel, saying that he repented that he had made Saul king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:3
verses.text: The priest reports what he had heard to the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:4
verses.text: And ere long, being instructed by God, he anointed David with the royal oil, while he was as yet only a little boy living under the care of his father, and acting as a shepherd, while he was accustomed often to play upon the harp.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:5
verses.text: For this reason, he was taken afterwards by Saul, and reckoned among the servants of the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:6
verses.text: And the Philistines and Hebrews being at this time hotly engaged in war, as the armies were stationed opposite to each other, a certain man of the Philistines named Goliath, a man of marvelous size and strength, passing along the ranks of his countrymen, cast insults, in the fiercest terms, upon the enemy, and challenged any one to engage in single combat with him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:7
verses.text: Then the king promised a great reward and his daughter in marriage to any one who should bring home the spoils of that boaster; but no one out of so great a multitude ventured to make the attempt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:8
verses.text: In these circumstances, though still a youth, David offered himself for the contest, and rejecting the arms by which his yet tender age was weighed down, simply with a staff and five stones which he had taken, advanced to the battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:9
verses.text: And by the first blow, having discharged one of the stones from a sling, he overthrew the Philistine; then he cut off the head of his conquered foe, carried off his spoils, and afterwards laid up his sword in the temple.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:10
verses.text: In the meanwhile, all the Philistines, turning to flight, yielded the victory to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:11
verses.text: But the great favor shown to David as they were returning from the battle excited the envy of the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:12
verses.text: Fearing, however, that if he put to death one so beloved by all, that might give rise to hatred against himself and prove disastrous, he resolved, under an appearance of doing him honor, to expose him to danger.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:13
verses.text: First then he made him a captain, that he might be charged with the affairs of war; and next, although he had promised him his daughter, he broke his word, and gave her to another.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:14
verses.text: Ere long, a younger daughter of the king, Melchol by name, fell violently in love with David.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:15
verses.text: Accordingly, Saul sets before David as the condition of obtaining her in marriage the following proposal: that if he should bring in a hundred foreskins of the enemy, the royal maiden would be given him in marriage; for he hoped that the youth, venturing on so great dangers, would probably perish.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 34:16
verses.text: But the result proved very different from what he imagined, for David, according to the proposal made to him, speedily brought in a hundred foreskins of the Philistines; and thus he obtained the daughter of the king in marriage.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:2
verses.text: The hatred of the king towards him increased daily, under the influence of jealousy, for the wicked always persecute the good.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:3
verses.text: He, therefore, commanded his servants and Jonathan his son, to prepare snares against his life.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:4
verses.text: But Jonathan had even from the first had a great  regard and affection for David; and therefore the king, being taken to task by his son, suppressed the cruel order he had given.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:5
verses.text: But the wicked are not long good.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:6
verses.text: For, when Saul was afflicted by a spirit of error, and David stood by him, soothing him with the harp under his trouble, Saul tried to pierce him with a spear, and would have done so, had not he rapidly evaded the deadly blow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:7
verses.text: From this time forth, the king no longer secretly but openly sought to compass his death; and David no longer trusted himself in his power.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:8
verses.text: He fled, and first betook himself to Samuel, then to Abimelech, and finally fled to the king of Moab.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:9
verses.text: By-and-by, under the instructions of the prophet Gad, he returned into the land of Judah, and there ran in danger of his life.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:10
verses.text: At that time, Saul slew Abimelech the priest because he had received David; and when none of the king's servants ventured to lay hands upon the priest, Doeg, the Syrian, fulfilled the cruel duty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:11
verses.text: After that, David made for the desert.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:12
verses.text: Thither Saul also followed him, but his efforts at his destruction were in vain, for God protected him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:13
verses.text: There was a cave in the desert, opening with a vast recess.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:14
verses.text: David had thrown himself into the inner parts of this cave.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:15
verses.text: Saul, not knowing that he was there, had gone into it for the purpose of taking bodily refreshment, and there, overcome by sleep, he was resting.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:16
verses.text: When David perceived this, although all urged him to avail himself of the opportunity, he abstained from slaying the king, and simply took away his mantle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:17
verses.text: Presently going out, he addressed the king from a safe position behind, recounting the services he had done him, how often he had exposed his life to peril for the sake of the kingdom, and how last of all, he had not, on the present occasion, sought to kill him when he was given over to him by God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:18
verses.text: Upon hearing these things, Saul confessed his fault, entreated pardon, shed tears, extolled the piety of David, and blamed his own wickedness, while he addressed David as king and son.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:19
verses.text: He was so much changed from his former ferocious character, that no one could now have thought he would make any further attempt against his son-in-law.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:20
verses.text: But David, who had thoroughly tested and known his evil disposition, did not think it safe to put himself in the power of the king, and kept himself within the desert.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:21
verses.text: Saul, almost mad with rage, because he was unable to capture his son-in-law, gave in marriage to one Faltim his daughter Melchol, who, as we have related above, had been married to David.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 35:22
verses.text: David fled to the Philistines.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:2
verses.text: At that time Samuel died.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:3
verses.text: Saul, when the Philistines made war upon him, consulted God, and no answer was returned to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:4
verses.text: Then, by means of a woman whose entrails a spirit of error had filled, he called up and consulted Samuel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:5
verses.text: Saul was informed by him that on the following day he with his sons, being overcome by the Philistines, would fall in the battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:6
verses.text: The Philistines, accordingly, having pitched their camp on the enemy's territory, drew up their army in battle array on the following day, David, however, being sent away from the camp, because they did not believe that he would be faithful to them against his own people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:7
verses.text: But the battle taking place, the Hebrews were routed and the sons of the king fell; Saul, having sunk down from his horse, that he might not be taken alive by the enemy, fell on his own sword.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:8
verses.text: We do not find any certain statements as to the length of his reign, unless that he is said in the Acts of the Apostles to have reigned forty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:9
verses.text: As to this, however, I am inclined to think that Paul, who made the statement in his preaching, then meant to include also the years of Samuel under the length of that king's reign.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:10
verses.text: Most of those, however, who have written about these times, remark that he reigned thirty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:11
verses.text: I can, by no means, agree with this opinion, for at the time when the ark of God was transferred to the town of Cariathiarim, Saul had not yet begun to reign, and it is related that the ark was removed by David the king out of that town after it had been there twenty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:12
verses.text: Therefore, since Saul reigned and died within that period, he must have held the government only for a very brief space of time.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:13
verses.text: We find the same obscurity concerning the times of Samuel, who, having been born under the priesthood of Eli, is related, when very old, to have fulfilled the duties of a priest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:14
verses.text: By some, however, who have written about these times (for the sacred history has recorded almost nothing about his years), but by most he is said to have ruled the people seventy years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:15
verses.text: I have, however, been unable to discover what authority there is for this assumption.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 36:16
verses.text: Amid such variety of error, we have followed the account of the Chronicles, because we think that it was taken (as said above) from the Acts of the Apostles, and we repeat that Samuel and Saul together held the government for forty years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:2
verses.text: Saul having thus been cut off, David, when the news of his death was brought to him in the land of the Philistines, is related to have wept, and to have given a marvelous proof of his affection.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:3
verses.text: He then betook himself to Hebron, a town of Judaea; and, being there again anointed with the royal oil, received the title of king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:4
verses.text: But Abenner, who had been master of the host of King Saul, despised David, and made Isbaal king, the son of King Saul.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:5
verses.text: Various battles then took place between the generals of the kings.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:6
verses.text: Abenner was generally routed; yet in his flight he cut off the brother of Joab, who had the command of the army on the side of David.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:7
verses.text: Joab, on account of the sorrow he felt for this, afterwards, when Abenner had surrendered to King David, ordered him to be murdered, not without regret on the part of the king, whose honor he had thus tarnished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:8
verses.text: At the same time, almost all the older men of the Hebrews conferred on him by public consent the sovereignty of the whole nation; for during seven years he had reigned only in Hebron.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:9
verses.text: Thus, he was anointed king for the third time, being about thirty years of age.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:10
verses.text: He repulsed in successful battles the Philistines making inroads upon his kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:11
verses.text: And at that time, he transferred to Zion the ark of God, which, as I have said above, was in the town of Cariathiarim.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:12
verses.text: And when he had formed the intention of building a temple to God, the divine answer was given him to the effect, that that was reserved for his son.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:13
verses.text: He then conquered the Philistines in war, subjugated the Moabites, and subdued Syria, imposing tribute upon it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:14
verses.text: He brought back with him an enormous amount of booty in gold and brass.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:15
verses.text: Next, a war arose against the Ammonites on account of the injury which had been done by their king, Annon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 37:16
verses.text: And when the Syrians again rebelled, having formed a confederacy for war with the Ammonites, David intrusted the chief command of the war to Joab, the master of his host, and he himself remained in Jerusalem far from the scene of strife.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:2
verses.text: At this time, he knew in a guilty way Bersabe, a woman of remarkable beauty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:3
verses.text: She is said to have been the wife of a certain man called Uriah, who was then in the camp.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:4
verses.text: David caused him to be slain by exposing him to the enemy at a dangerous place in the battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:5
verses.text: In this way, he added to the number of his wives the woman who was now free from the bond of marriage, but who was already pregnant through adultery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:6
verses.text: Then David, after being severely reproved by Nathan the prophet, although he confessed his sin, did not escape the punishment of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:7
verses.text: For he lost in a few days the son who was born from the clandestine connection, and many terrible things happened in respect to his house and family.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:8
verses.text: At last his son Absalom lifted impious arms against his father, with the desire of driving him from the throne.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:9
verses.text: Joab encountered him in the field of battle, and the king entreated him to spare the young man when conquered; but he, disregarding this command, avenged with the sword his parricidal attempts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:10
verses.text: That victory is said to have been a mournful one to the king: so great was his natural affection that he wished even his parricidal son to be forgiven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:11
verses.text: This war seemed hardly finished when another arose, under a certain general called Sabaea, who had stirred up all the wicked to arms.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:12
verses.text: But the whole commotion was speedily checked by the death of the leader.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:13
verses.text: David then engaged in several battles against the Philistines with favorable results; and all being subdued by war, both foreign and home disturbances having been brought to accord, he possessed in peace a most flourishing kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:14
verses.text: Then a sudden desire seized him of numbering the people, in order to ascertain the strength of his empire; and accordingly they were numbered by Joab, the master of the host, and were found to amount to one million three hundred thousand citizens.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:15
verses.text: David soon regretted and repented of this proceeding, and implored pardon of God for having lifted up his thoughts to this, that he should reckon the power of his kingdom rather by the multitude of his subjects than by the divine favor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:16
verses.text: Accordingly, an angel was sent to him to reveal to him a threefold punishment, and to give him the power of choosing either one or another.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:17
verses.text: Well, when a famine for three years was set before him, and flight before his enemies for three months, and a pestilence for three days, shunning both flight and famine, he made choice of pestilence, and, almost in a moment of time, seventy thousand men perished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:18
verses.text: Then David, beholding the angel by whose right hand the people were overthrown, implored pardon, and offered himself singly to punishment instead of all, saying that he deserved destruction inasmuch as it was he who had sinned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:19
verses.text: Thus, the punishment of the people was turned aside; and David built an altar to God on the spot where he had beheld the angel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:20
verses.text: After this, having become infirm through years and illness, he appointed Solomon, who had been born to him by Bersabe, the wife of Uriah, his successor in the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:21
verses.text: He, having been anointed with the royal oil by  Sadoc the priest, received the title of king, while his father was still alive.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 38:22
verses.text: David died, after he had reigned forty years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:2
verses.text: Solomon in the beginning of his reign surrounded the city with a wall.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:3
verses.text: To him while asleep God appeared standing by him, and gave him the choice of whatever things he desired.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:4
verses.text: But he asked that nothing more than wisdom should be granted him, deeming all other things of little value.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:5
verses.text: Accordingly, when he arose from sleep, taking his stand before the sanctuary of God, he gave a proof of the wisdom which had been bestowed upon him by God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:6
verses.text: For two women who dwelt in one house, having given birth to male children at the same time, and one of these having died in the night three days afterwards, the mother of the dead child, while the other woman slept, insidiously substituted her child, and took away the living one.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:7
verses.text: Then there arose an altercation between them, and the matter was at length brought before the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:8
verses.text: As no witness was forthcoming, it was a difficult matter to give a judgment between both denying guilt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:9
verses.text: Then Solomon, in the exercise of his gift of divine wisdom, ordered the child to be slain and its body to be divided between the two doubtful claimants.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:10
verses.text: Well, when one of them acquiesced in this judgment, but the other wished rather to give up the boy than that he should be cut in pieces, Solomon, concluding from the feeling displayed by this woman that she was the true mother, adjudged the child to her.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:11
verses.text: The bystanders could not repress their admiration at this decision, since he had in such a way brought out the hidden truth by his sagacity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 39:12
verses.text: Accordingly, the kings of the neighboring nations, out of admiration for his ability and wisdom, courted his friendship and alliance, being prepared to carry out his commands.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:1
verses.text: Chapter XL.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:2
verses.text: Trusting in these resources, Solomon set about erecting a temple of immense size to God, funds for the purpose having been got together during three years, and laid the foundation of it about the fourth year of his reign.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:3
verses.text: This was about the five hundred and eighty-eighth year after the departure of the Hebrews from Egypt, although in the third Book of Kings the years are reckoned at four hundred and forty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:4
verses.text: This is by no means accurate; for it would have been more likely that, in the order of dates I have given above, I should perhaps reckon fewer years than more.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:5
verses.text: But I do not doubt that the truth had been falsified by the carelessness of copyists, especially since so many ages intervened, rather than that the sacred writer erred.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:6
verses.text: In the same way, in the case of this little work of ours, we believe it will happen that, through the negligence of transcribers, those things which have been put together, not without care on our part, should be corrupted.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:7
verses.text: Well, then, Solomon finished his work of building the temple in the twentieth year from its commencement.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:8
verses.text: Then, having offered sacrifice in that place, as well as uttered a prayer, by which he blessed the people and the temple, God spoke to him, declaring that, if at any time they should sin and forsake God, their temple should be razed to the ground.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:9
verses.text: We see that this has a long time ago been fulfilled, and in due time we shall set forth the connected order of events.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:10
verses.text: In the meantime, Solomon abounded in wealth, and was, in fact, the richest of all the kings that ever lived.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:11
verses.text: But, as always takes place in such circumstances, he sunk from wealth into luxury and vice, forming marriages (in spite of the prohibition of God) with foreign women, until he had seven hundred wives, and three hundred concubines.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:12
verses.text: As a consequence, he set up idols for them, after the manner of their nations, to which they might offer sacrifice.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:13
verses.text: God, turned away from him by such doings, reproved him sharply, and made known to him as a punishment, that the greater part of his kingdom would be taken from his son, and given to a servant.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 40:14
verses.text: And that happened accordingly.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:1
verses.text: Chapter XLI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:2
verses.text: For, on the death of Solomon in the fortieth year of his reign, Roboam his son having succeeded to the throne of his father in the sixteenth year of his age, a portion of the people, taking offense, revolted from him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:3
verses.text: For, having asked that the very heavy tribute which Solomon had imposed upon them might be lessened, he rejected the entreaties of these suppliants, and thus alienated from him the favor of the whole people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:4
verses.text: Accordingly, by universal consent, the government was bestowed on Jeroboam.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:5
verses.text: He, sprung from a family of middle rank, had for some time been in the service of Solomon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:6
verses.text: But when the king found that the sovereignty of the Hebrews had been promised to him by a response of the prophet Achia, he had resolved privately to cut him off.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:7
verses.text: Jeroboam, under the influence of this fear, fled into Egypt, and there married a wife of the royal family.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:8
verses.text: But, when at length he heard of the death of Solomon, he returned to his native land, and, by the wish of the people, as we have said above, he assumed the government.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:9
verses.text: Two tribes, however, Judah and Benjamin, had remained under the sway of Roboam; and from these he got ready an army of thirty thousand men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:10
verses.text: But when the two hosts advanced, the people were instructed by the words of God to abstain from fighting, for that Jeroboam had received the kingdom by divine appointment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:11
verses.text: Thus the army disdained the command of the king, and dispersed, while the power of Jeroboam was increased.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:12
verses.text: But, since Roboam held Jerusalem, where the people had been accustomed to offer sacrifice to God in the temple built by Solomon, Jeroboam, fearing lest their religious feelings might alienate the people from him, resolved to fill their minds with superstition.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:13
verses.text: Accordingly, he set up one golden calf at Bethel, and another at Dan, to which the people might offer sacrifice; and, passing by the tribe of Levi, he appointed priests from among the people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:14
verses.text: But censure followed this guilt so hateful to God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:15
verses.text: Frequent battles then took place between the kings, and so they retained their respective kingdoms on doubtful conditions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 41:16
verses.text: Roboam died at the close of the seventeenth year of his reign.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:1
verses.text: Chapter XLII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:2
verses.text: In his room Abiud his son held the kingdom at Jerusalem for six years, although he is said in the Chronicles to have reigned three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:3
verses.text: Asab his son succeeded him, being the fifth from David, as he was his great-great-grandson.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:4
verses.text: He was a pious worshiper of God; for, destroying the altars and the groves of the idols, he removed the traces of his father's faithlessness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:5
verses.text: He formed an alliance with the king of Syria, and by his help inflicted much loss on the kingdom of Jeroboam, which was then held by his son, and often, after conquering the enemy, carried off spoil as the result of victory.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:6
verses.text: After forty-one years he died, afflicted with disease in his feet.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:7
verses.text: To him sin of a three-fold kind is ascribed; first, that he trusted too much to his alliance with the king of Syria; secondly, that he cast into prison a prophet of God who rebuked him for this; and thirdly, that, when suffering from disease in his feet, he sought a remedy, not from God, but from the physicians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:8
verses.text: In the beginning of his reign died Jeroboam, king of the ten tribes, and left his throne to his son Nabath.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:9
verses.text: He, from his wicked works, and, both by his own and his father's doings, hateful to God, did not possess the kingdom more than two years, and his children, as being unworthy, were deprived of the government.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:10
verses.text: He had for his successor Baasa, the son of Achia, and he proved himself equally estranged from God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:11
verses.text: He died in the twenty-sixth year of his reign: and his power passed to Ela his son, but was not retained more than two years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:12
verses.text: For Zambri, leader of his cavalry, killed him at a banquet, and seized the kingdom,—a man equally odious to God and men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:13
verses.text: A portion of the people revolted from him, and the royal power was conferred on one Thamnis.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:14
verses.text: But Zambri reigned before him seven years, and at the same time with him twelve years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:15
verses.text: And, on the death of Asab, Josaphat his son began to reign over part of the tribe of Judah, a man deservedly famous for his pious virtues.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 42:16
verses.text: He lived at peace with Zambri; and he died, after a reign of twenty-five years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:2
verses.text: In the time of his reign, Ahab, the son of Ambri, was king of the ten tribes, impious above all against God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:3
verses.text: For having taken in marriage Jezebel, the daughter of Basa, king of Sidon, he erected an altar and groves to the idol Bahal, and slew the prophets of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:4
verses.text: At this time, Elijah the prophet by prayer shut up heaven, that it should not give any rain to the earth, and revealed that to the king, in order that he, in his impiety, might know himself to be the cause of the evil.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:5
verses.text: The waters of heaven, therefore, being restrained, and since the whole country, burned up by the heat of the sun, did not furnish food either for man or beast, the prophet had even exposed himself to the side of perishing from hunger.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:6
verses.text: At that time, when he betook himself to the desert, he depended for life on the ravens furnishing him with food, while a neighboring rivulet furnished him with water, until it was dried up.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:7
verses.text: Then, being instructed by God, he went to the town of Saraptae, and turned aside to lodge with a widow-woman.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:8
verses.text: And when, in his hunger, he begged food from her, she complained that she had only a handful of meal and a little oil, on the consumption of which she expected death along with her children.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:9
verses.text: But when Elijah promised in the words of God that neither should the meal lessen in the barrel nor the oil in the vessel, the woman did not hesitate to believe the prophet demanding faith, and obtained the fulfillment of what was promised, since by daily increase as much  was added as was day by day taken away.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:10
verses.text: At the same time, Elijah restored to life the dead son of the same widow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:11
verses.text: Then, by the command of God, he went to the king, and having reproved his impiety, he ordered all the people to be gathered together to himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:12
verses.text: When these had hastily assembled, the priests of the idols and of the groves to the number of about four hundred and fifty, were also summoned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:13
verses.text: Then there arose a dispute between them, Elijah setting forth the honor of God, while they upheld their own superstitions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:14
verses.text: At length they agreed that a trial should be made to this effect, that if fire sent down from heaven should consume the slain victim of either of them, that religion should be accepted as the true one which performed the miracle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:15
verses.text: Accordingly, the priests, having slain a calf, began to call upon the idol Bahal; and, after wasting their invocations to no purpose, they tacitly acknowledged the helplessness of their God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:16
verses.text: Then Elijah mocked them and said, "Cry aloud more vehemently, lest perchance he sleeps, and that thus you may rouse him from the slumber in which he is sunk".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:17
verses.text: The wretched men could do nothing but shudder and mutter to themselves, but still they waited to see what Elijah would do.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:18
verses.text: Well, he slew a calf and laid it upon the altar, having first of all filled the sacred place with water; and then, calling upon the name of the Lord, fire fell from heaven in the sight of all, and consumed alike the water and the victim.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:19
verses.text: Then truly the people, casting themselves upon the earth, confessed God and execrated the idols; while finally, by the command of Elijah, the impious priests were seized, and, being brought down to the brook, were there slain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:20
verses.text: The prophet followed the king as he returned from that place; but as Jezebel, the wife of the king, was devising means for taking his life, he retired to a more remote spot.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:21
verses.text: There God addressed him, telling him that there were still seven thousand men who had not given themselves up to idols.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 43:22
verses.text: That was to Elijah a marvelous statement, for he had supposed that he himself was the only one who had kept free from impiety.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:2
verses.text: At that time, Ahab, king of Samaria, coveted the vineyard of Naboth, which was adjacent to his own.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:3
