verses.text: And as Naboth was unwilling to sell it to him, he was cut off by the wiles of Jezebel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:4
verses.text: Thus Ahab got possession of the vineyard, though he is said at the same time to have regretted the death of Naboth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:5
verses.text: Acknowledging his crime, he is related to have done penance clothed in sackcloth; and in this way he turned aside threatening punishment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:6
verses.text: For the king of Syria with a great army, having formed a military confederacy with thirty-two kings, entered the territories of Samaria, and began to besiege the city with its king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:7
verses.text: The affairs of the besieged being then in a state of great distress, the Syrian king offers these conditions in the war,—if they should give up their gold and silver and women, he would spare their lives.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:8
verses.text: But, with such iniquitous conditions offered, it seemed better to suffer the greatest extremities.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:9
verses.text: And now when the safety of all was despaired of, a prophet sent by God went to the king, encouraged him to go forth to battle, and when he hesitated, strengthened his confidence in many ways.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:10
verses.text: Accordingly making a sally, the enemy were routed, and an abundant store of booty was secured.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:11
verses.text: But, after a year, the Syrian king returned with recruited strength into Samaria, burning to avenge the defeat he had received, but was again overthrown.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:12
verses.text: In that battle one hundred and twenty thousand of the Syrians perished; the king was pardoned, and his kingdom and former position were granted him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:13
verses.text: Then Ahab was reproved by the prophet in the words of God, for having abused the divine kindness, and spared the enemy delivered up to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:14
verses.text: The Syrian king, therefore, after three years, made war upon the Hebrews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:15
verses.text: Against him Ahab, under the advice of some false prophet, went forth to battle, having spurned the words of Michea the prophet and cast him into prison, because the prophet had warned him that the fight would prove disastrous to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 44:16
verses.text: Thus, then, Ahab, being slain in that battle, left the kingdom to his son Ochozia.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:1
verses.text: Chapter XLV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:2
verses.text: He, being sick in body, and having sent some of his servants to consult an idol about his recovery, Elijah, as instructed by God, met them in the way, and, after rebuking them ordered them to inform the king that his death would follow from that disease.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:3
verses.text: Then the king ordered him to be seized and brought into his presence, but those who were sent for this purpose were consumed by fire from heaven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:4
verses.text: The king died, as the prophet had predicted.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:5
verses.text: To him there succeeded his brother Joram; and he held the government for the space of twelve years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:6
verses.text: But on the side of the two tribes, Josaphat the king having died, Joram his son possessed the kingdom for eighteen years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:7
verses.text: He had the daughter of Ahab to wife, and proved himself more like his father-in-law than his father.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:8
verses.text: After him, Ochozias his son obtained the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:9
verses.text: During his reign, Elijah is related to have been taken up to heaven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:10
verses.text: At the same time,  Elisha his disciple showed himself powerful by working many miracles, which are all too well known to need any description from my pen.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:11
verses.text: By him the son of a widow was restored to life, a leper of Syria was cleansed, at a time of famine abundance of all things was brought into the city by the enemy having been put to flight, water was furnished for the use of three armies, and from a little oil the debt of a woman was paid by the oil being immensely multiplied, and sufficient means for a livelihood was provided for herself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:12
verses.text: In his times, as we have said, Ochozia was king of the two tribes, while Joram, as we have related above, ruled over the ten; and an alliance was formed between them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 45:13
verses.text: For war was carried on by them with combined forces both against the Syrians, and against Jeu, who had been anointed by the prophet as king of the ten tribes; and having gone forth to battle in company, they both perished in the same fight.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:2
verses.text: But Jeu possessed the kingdom of Joram.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:3
verses.text: After the death of Ochozia in Judaea, when he had reigned one year, his mother, Gotholiah, seized the supreme power, having deprived her grandson (whose name was Joas) of the government, he being at the time but a little child.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:4
verses.text: But the power thus snatched from him by his grandmother was, after eight years, restored to him through means of the priests and people, while his grandmother was driven into exile.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:5
verses.text: He, at the beginning of his reign, was most devoted to the divine worship, and embellished the temple at great expense; afterwards, however, being corrupted by the flattery of the chief men, and unduly honored by them, he incurred wrath.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:6
verses.text: For Azahel, king of Syria, made war upon him; and, as things went badly with him, he purchased peace with the gold of the temple.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:7
verses.text: He did not, however, obtain it; but through resentment for what he had done he was slain by his own people in the fortieth year of his reign.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:8
verses.text: He was succeeded by his son Amassia.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:9
verses.text: But, on the side of the ten tribes, Jeu having died, Joachas his son began to reign, displeasing to God on account of his wicked works, in punishment of which his kingdom was ravaged by the Syrians, until, through the mercy of God, the enemy was driven back, and the inhabitants of the land began to occupy their former position.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:10
verses.text: Joachas, having ended his days, left the kingdom to his son Joa.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:11
verses.text: He raised civil war against Amassia, king of the two tribes; and, having obtained the victory, conveyed much spoil into his own kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:12
verses.text: That is related to have occurred to Amassia as a punishment of his sin, for, having entered as a conqueror the territories of the Idumaeans, he had adopted the idols of that nation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:13
verses.text: He is described as having reigned nine years, so far as I find it stated in the Books of Kings.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:14
verses.text: But in the Chronicles of Scripture, as well as in the Chronicles of Eusebius, he is affirmed to have held the government twenty-nine years; and the mode of reckoning which may easily be perceived in these Books of Kings undoubtedly leads to that conclusion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:15
verses.text: For Jeroboam is said to have begun to reign as king of the ten tribes in the eighth year of the reign of Amassia, and to have held the government forty-one years, and to have at length died in the fourth year of the reign of Ozia, son of Amassia.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:16
verses.text: By this mode of reckoning, the reign of Amassia is made to extend over twenty-eight years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 46:17
verses.text: Accordingly, we, following out this, inasmuch as it is our purpose to adhere in this work to the dates in their proper order, have accepted the authority of the Chronicles.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:2
verses.text: Ozias, then, the son of Amassia, succeeded to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:3
verses.text: For, on the side of the ten tribes, Joas, reaching the end of his days, had given place to his son Jeroboa, and after him, again, his son Zacharias began to reign.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:4
verses.text: Of these kings, and of all who ruled over Samaria on the side of the ten tribes, we have not thought it necessary to note the dates, because, aiming at brevity, we have omitted everything superfluous; and we have thought that the years should be carefully traced for a knowledge especially of the times of that portion of the Jews, which being carried into captivity at a later period than the other, passed through a longer time as a kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:5
verses.text: Ozias, then, having obtained the kingdom of Judah, gave his principal care to knowing the Lord, making great use of Zachariah the prophet (Isaiah, too, is said to have first prophesied under this king); and, on this account, he carried on war against his neighbors with deservedly prosperous results, while he also conquered the Arabians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:6
verses.text: And already he had shaken Egypt with the terror of his name; but, being elated by prosperity, he ventured on what was forbidden, and offered incense to God, a thing which it was the established custom for the priests alone to do.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:7
verses.text: Being, then, rebuked by Azaria the priest, and compelled to leave the sacred place, he burst out into a rage, but was, when he finally withdrew, covered with leprosy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:8
verses.text: Under the influence of this disease he ended his  days, after having reigned fifty-two years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:9
verses.text: Then the kingdom was given to Joathas his son; and he is related to have been very pious, and carried on the government with success: he subdued in war the nation of the Ammonites, and compelled them to pay tribute.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 47:10
verses.text: He reigned sixteen years, and his son Achaz succeeded him.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:2
verses.text: The remarkable faith of the Ninevites is related to have been manifested about these times.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:3
verses.text: That town, founded of old by Assure, the son of Sem, was the capital of the kingdom of the Assyrians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:4
verses.text: It was then full of a multitude of inhabitants, sustaining one hundred and twenty thousand men, and abounding in wickedness, as is usually the case among a vast concourse of people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:5
verses.text: God, moved by their sinfulness, commanded the prophet Jonah to go from Judaea, and denounce destruction upon the city, as Sodom and Gomorrah had of old been consumed by fire from heaven.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:6
verses.text: But the prophet declined that office of preaching, not out of contumacy, but from foresight, which enabled him to behold God reconciled through the repentance of the people; and he embarked on board a ship which was bound for Tharsus, in a very different direction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:7
verses.text: But, after they had gone forth into the deep, the sailors, constrained by the violence of the sea, inquired by means of the lot who was the cause of that suffering.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:8
verses.text: And when the lot fell upon Jonah, he was cast into the sea, to be, as it were, a sacrifice for stilling the tempest, and he was seized and swallowed by a whale—a monster of the deep.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:9
verses.text: Cast out three days afterwards on the shores of the Ninevites, he preached as he had been commanded, namely that the city would be destroyed in three days, as a punishment for the sins of the people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:10
verses.text: The voice of the prophet was listened to, not in a hypocritical fashion, as at Sodom of old; and immediately by the order, and after the example, of the king, the whole people, and even those infants newly born, are commanded to abstain from meat and drink: the very beasts of burden in the place, and animals of different kinds, being forced by hunger and thirst, presented an appearance of those who lamented along with the human inhabitants.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:11
verses.text: In this way, the threatened evil was averted.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 48:12
verses.text: To Jonah, complaining to God, that his words had not been fulfilled, it was answered that pardon could never be denied to the penitent.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:2
verses.text: But in Samaria, Zacharia the king, who was very wicked, and whom we have spoken of above as occupying the throne, was slain by a certain Sella, who seized the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:3
verses.text: He, in turn, perished by the treachery of Mane, who simply repeated the conduct of his predecessor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:4
verses.text: Mane held the government which he had taken from Sella, and left it to his son Pache.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:5
verses.text: But a certain person of the same name slew Pache, and seized the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:6
verses.text: Ere long being cut off by Osee, he lost the sovereignty by the same crime by which he had received it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:7
verses.text: This man, being ungodly beyond all the kings who had preceded him, brought punishment upon himself from God, and a perpetual captivity on his nation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:8
verses.text: For Salmanasar, king of the Assyrians, made war with him, and when conquered rendered him tributary.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:9
verses.text: But when, with secret plans, he was preparing for rebellion, and had asked the king of the Ethiopians, who then had possession of Egypt for his assistance, Salmanasar, on discovering that, cast him into prison with fetters never taken off, while he destroyed the city, and carried off the whole people into his own kingdom, Assyrians being placed in the enemy's country to guard it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:10
verses.text: Hence that district was called Samaria, because in the language of the Assyrians guards are called Samaritae.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:11
verses.text: Very many of their settlers accepted the divine rites of the Jewish religion, while others remained in the errors of heathenism.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:12
verses.text: In this war, Tobias was carried into captivity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:13
verses.text: But on the side of the two tribes, Achaz, who was displeasing to God on account of his impiety, finding he had frequently the worst of it in wars with his neighbors, resolved to worship the gods of the heathen, undoubtedly because by their help his enemies had proved victorious in frequent battles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 49:14
verses.text: He ended his days with this crime in his wicked mind, after a reign of sixteen years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:1
verses.text: Chapter L.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:2
verses.text: To him succeeded Ezekias his son, a man very unlike his father in character.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:3
verses.text: For, in the beginning of his reign, urging the people and the priests to the worship of God, he discoursed to them in many words, showing how often, after being chastened by the Lord, they had obtained mercy, and how the ten tribes, having been at last carried away into captivity, as had lately happened, were now paying the penalty of their impiety.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:4
verses.text: He added that their duty was carefully to be on their guard lest they should deserve to suffer the same things.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:5
verses.text: Thus, the  minds of all being turned to religion, he appointed the Levites and all the priests to offer sacrifices according to the law, and arranged that the Passover, which had for a long time been neglected, should be celebrated.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:6
verses.text: And when the holy day was at hand, he proclaimed the special day of assembly by messengers sent throughout all the land, so that, if any had remained in Samaria, after the removal of the ten tribes, they might gather together for the sacred observance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:7
verses.text: Thus, in a very full assemblage, the sacred day was spent with public rejoicing, and, after a long interval, the proper religious rites were restored by means of Ezekias.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:8
verses.text: He then carried on military affairs with the same diligence with which he had attended to divine things, and defeated the Philistines in frequent battles; until Sennacherim, king of the Assyrians, made war against him, having entered his territories with a large army; and then, when the country had been laid waste without any opposition, he laid siege to the city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:9
verses.text: For Ezekias, being inferior in numbers, did not venture to come to an engagement with him, but kept himself safe within the walls.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:10
verses.text: The king of Assyria, thundering at the gates, threatened destruction, and demanded surrender, exclaiming that in vain did Ezekias put his trust in God, for that he rather had taken up arms by the appointment of God; and that the conqueror of all nations, as well as the overthrower of Samaria could not be escaped, unless the king secured his own safety by a speedy surrender.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:11
verses.text: In this state of affairs, Ezekias, trusting in God, consulted the prophet Isaiah, and from his answer he learned that there would be no danger from the enemy, and that the divine assistance would not fail him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 50:12
verses.text: And, in fact, not long after, Tarraca, king of Ethiopia, invaded the kingdom of the Assyrians.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:1
verses.text: Chapter LI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:2
verses.text: By this news Sennacherim was led to return in order to defend his own territories, and he gave up the war, at the same time murmuring and crying out that victory was snatched from him the victor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:3
verses.text: He also sent letters to Ezekias, declaring, with many insulting words, that he, after settling his own affairs, would speedily return for the destruction of Judaea.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:4
verses.text: But Ezekias, in no wise disturbed by these threats, is said to have prayed to God that he would not allow the so great insolence of this man to pass unavenged.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:5
verses.text: Accordingly, in the same night, an angel attacking the camp of the Assyrians, caused the death of many thousand men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:6
verses.text: The king in terror fled to the town of Nineveh, and being there slain by his sons, met with an end worthy of himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:7
verses.text: At the same time, Ezekias, sick in body, lay suffering from disease.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:8
verses.text: And when Isaiah had announced to him in the words of the Lord that the end of his life was at hand, the king is related to have wept; and thus he got fifteen years added to his life.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:9
verses.text: These coming to an end, he died in the twenty-ninth year of his reign, and left the kingdom to his son Manasse.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:10
verses.text: He, degenerating much from his father, forsook God, and took to the practice of impious worship; and being, as a punishment for this, delivered into the power of the Assyrians, he was by his sufferings constrained to acknowledge his error, and exhorted the people that, forsaking their idols, they should worship God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:11
verses.text: He accomplished nothing worthy of special mention, but reigned for fifty-five years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:12
verses.text: Then Amos his son obtained the kingdom, but possessed it only two years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 51:13
verses.text: He was the heir of his father's impiety, and showed himself regardless of God: being entrapped by some stratagems of his friends, he perished.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:1
verses.text: Chapter LII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:2
verses.text: The government then passed to his son Josia.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:3
verses.text: He is related to have been very pious, and to have attended to divine things with the utmost care, profiting largely by the aid of the priest Helchia.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:4
verses.text: Having read a book written with the words of God, and which had been found in the temple by the priest, in which it was stated that the Hebrew nation would be destroyed on account of their frequent acts of impiety and sacrilege, by his pious supplications to God, and constant tears, he averted the impending overthrow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:5
verses.text: When he learned through Olda the prophetess that this favor was granted him, he then with still greater care set himself to practice the worship of God, inasmuch as he was now under obligation to the divine goodness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:6
verses.text: Accordingly, he burned all the vessels which had by the superstitions of former kings been consecrated to idols.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:7
verses.text: For to such a height had profane observances prevailed, that they used to pay divine honors to the sun and moon, and even erected shrines made of metal to these fancied deities.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:8
verses.text: Josia reduced these to powder, and also slew the priests of the profane temples.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:9
verses.text: He did not even spare the tombs of the impious; and it was observed that thus was fulfilled what had of old been predicted by the prophet.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:10
verses.text: In the eighteenth year of his reign, the Passover was celebrated.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:11
verses.text: And about three years afterwards, having gone forth to battle against Nechao, king of Egypt, who was making war upon the Assyrians, before the armies properly engaged, he was wounded by an arrow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 52:12
verses.text: And being carried back to the city, he died of that wound, after he had reigned twenty and one years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:1
verses.text: Chapter LIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:2
verses.text: Joachas, his son, having then obtained the kingdom, held it for three months, being doomed to captivity on account of his impiety.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:3
verses.text: For Nechao, king of Egypt, bound him and led him away captive, and not long after, while still a prisoner, he ended his days.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:4
verses.text: An annual tribute was demanded of the Jews, and a king was given them at the will of the victor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:5
verses.text: His name was Eliakim, but he afterwards changed it to Joachim.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:6
verses.text: He was the brother of Joacha, and the son of Josia, but liker his brother than his father, displeasing God by his impiety.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:7
verses.text: Accordingly, while he was in subjection to the king of Egypt, and in token thereof paid him tribute, Nabuchodonosor, the king of Babylon, seized the land of Judaea, and as victor held it by the right of war for three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:8
verses.text: For the king of Egypt now giving way, and the boundaries of their empire being fixed between them, it had been agreed that the Jews should belong to Babylon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:9
verses.text: Thus after Joachim, having finished his reign of eleven years, had given place to his son of the same name, and he had excited against himself the wrath of the king of Babylon (God undoubtedly overruling everything, having resolved to give the nation of the Jews up to captivity and destruction), Nabuchodonosor entered Jerusalem with an army, and leveled the walls and the temple to the ground.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:10
verses.text: He also carried off an immense amount of gold, with sacred ornaments either public or private, and all of mature age both of the male and female sex, those only being left behind whose weakness or age caused trouble to the conquerors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:11
verses.text: This useless crowd had the task assigned them of working and cultivating the fields in slavery, in order that the soil might not be neglected.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:12
verses.text: Over them a king called Sedechias was appointed; but while the empty shadow of the name of king was allowed him, all real power was taken away.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:13
verses.text: Joachim, for his part, possessed the sovereignty only for three months.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 53:14
verses.text: He was carried away, along with the people, to Babylon, and was there thrown into prison; but being, after a period of thirty years released, while he was admitted by the king to his friendship, and made a partaker with him at his table and in his counsels, he died at last, not without some consolation in that his misfortunes had been removed.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:1
verses.text: Chapter LIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:2
verses.text: Meanwhile Sedechias, the king of the useless multitude, although without power, being of an unfaithful disposition and neglectful of God, and not understanding that captivity had been brought upon them on account of the sins of the nation, becoming at length ripe for suffering the last evils he could endure, offended the mind of the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:3
verses.text: Accordingly, after a period of nine years, Nabuchodonosor made war against him, and having forced him to flee within the walls, besieged him for three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:4
verses.text: At this time, he consulted Jeremia the prophet, who had already often proclaimed that captivity impended over the city, to discover if perhaps there might still be some hope.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:5
verses.text: But he, not ignorant of the anger of heaven, having frequently had the same question put to him, at length gave an answer, denouncing special punishment upon the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:6
verses.text: Then Sedechias, roused to resentment, ordered the prophet to be thrust into prison.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:7
verses.text: Ere long, however, he regretted this cruel act, but, as the chief men of the Jews (whose practice it had been even from the beginning to afflict the righteous) opposed him, he did not venture to release the innocent man.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:8
verses.text: Under coercion from the same persons, the prophet was let down into a pit of great depth, and which was disgusting from its filth and squalor, while a deadly stench issued from it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:9
verses.text: This was done that he might not simply die by a common death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:10
verses.text: But the king, impious though he was, yet showed himself somewhat more merciful than the priests, and ordered the prophet to be taken out of the pit, and restored to the safekeeping of the prison.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:11
verses.text: In the meantime the force of the enemy and want began to press the besieged hard, and everything being consumed that could be eaten, famine took a firm hold of them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:12
verses.text: Thus, its defenders being worn out with want of food, the town was taken and burnt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:13
verses.text: The king, as the prophet had declared, had his eyes put out, and was carried away to Babylon, while Jeremia, through the mercy of the enemy, was taken out of his prison.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:14
verses.text: When Nabuzardan, one of the royal princes, was leading him away captive with the rest, the choice was granted by him to the prophet, either to remain in his deserted and desolated native country, or to go along with him in the possession of the highest honors; and Jeremia preferred to abide in his native land.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:15
verses.text: Nabuchodonosor, having carried away the people, appointed as governor over those left behind by the conquerors (either from the circumstances attending the war, or from an absolute weariness of accumulating spoil) Godolia, who belonged to the same nation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book I 54:16
verses.text: He gave  him, however, no royal ensign, or even the name of governor, because there was really no honor in ruling over these few wretched persons.
